description:
This spot is such a hidden gem! IMO it's more authentic than any other spot in Chinatown, and more convenient than venturing out into Richmond/Sunset (for downtown SF folks like me). This place is so low-key that, despite having lived in the city for several years, this past weekend was my first time hearing about it. 

My friend and I came here at 12:30pm on a Sunday, and we were seated within 15 minutes. There was a small crowd when we arrived, but the line moved fast. 

My favorite items that we ordered: 

1. Steamed BBQ Pork Bun (cha siu bao) - 5/5
Wow, we were *muy* impressed. Fresh pork and the perfect pork-to-sauce-to-bun ratio, nestled in a soft, fluffy bun. 

2. BBQ Pork Noodle Roll (cheong fun) - 5/5
The skin was *on point* (the make-it-or-break-it factor for cheong fun). I've had so many "soggy" cheong fun experiences in the city that I was convinced I'd have to go back to HK for legit cheong fun. Happy to say that Dim Sum Club's cheong fun is legit!

3. Pan Fried Turnip Cake (loh bat go) - 5/5
Perfectly pan-fried with a crispy top layer, and not at all greasy!

4. Pork & Shrimp Siu Mai - 5/5
A HK girl knows a good siu mai when she has one (:

We also ordered the Preserved Egg w/ Pork Porridge (comes with a side of Chinese fried donut) and Stuffed Eggplant w/ Black Bean Sauce, but those were meh. I'd recommend saving your tummy for their other items.

All in all, I was very impressed with Dim Sum Club and highly recommend all you dim sum lovers give it a try!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Not in a typical location for dim sum since it isn't inside Chinatown....it was still very close to our motel in a residential neighborhood next to a hotel and was a quick enough walk that we decided to check it out after finding the pretty decent reviews on Yelp.

We walked in and it was relatively busy but were still seated quickly.  The server was quick to set our table, we passed on the tea due to an upcharge (seems to be a thing in SF).  The older gentleman watching over everything was super nice and came over to us to chat for a bit at the end of the meal.  

I loved their take on the shrimp & chive dumpling, you can see it from my pictures....they were more like globs and not closed off on top but super yummy.  The scallion pancakes were a bit too thin and fell a part in your hand.  The salt & pepper tofu was anything but and probably the biggest disappointment overall, not what I was expecting and practically flavorless.  The chicken feet were some of the biggest and meatiest I've ever had, the star of the show here....if I could get those shipped back home 3000 miles I totally would do it.    

The prices keep it from being a full five stars, we stuck to the cheaper options and still had a bill over $40 for what didn't seem like a lot of dishes.  At least all of the prices are posted on the menu, many dim sum places don't do that for you.  If you live in the area, this will definitely do the trick to get your Chinese brunch fix in.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Low-key, not-sure-if-it's-any-good frontage and decor, but don't let it fool you. The dim sum here is AMAZING. I have searched around SF for decent dim sum, and convinced myself that a few (not to be named) spots were good. This is the spot that reminded me I was kidding myself with the other restaurants. 

Recommendations: Shrimp dumplings, spare ribs, Shanghai dumplings, sticky rice in lotus leaf 

Pros:
- Every dish we had 
- Friendly, quick service 
- No line 
- Reasonable price ($25 each and we stuffed our faces)

Okays: 
- Tea wasn't super satisfying 

Cons:
- N/a
author: Perry H.

description: I came here based on Yelp recommendation, and it's pretty good Dim Sum for an exotic location. The service was friendly and the most importantly, the dim sum was hot and tasty and very affordable.
author: Andrea Y.

description: Got here at 2:50 when advertised open until 3pm.  Were refused service and told they were closed.  We had driven over one half hour to get there, very rude especially aince there were several people still dining.
author: Robin M.

description: Still the best dim sum I've had in SF. Reliable and charming, with efficient service. It keeps getting more and more crowded but still a bit of a hidden gem.
author: Alex C.

description:
yummy & no frills, no chaos of chinatown. 

I would not recommend the buddha veggie noodle roll - it tasted a little strange to me, but the shrimp noodle roll was great. If you're vegetarian, there's another veggie noodle roll i'd try instead.
author: Cindy L.

description:
-great prices, fast and very friendly service 
-my favorites were the shrimp dumpling and the pork and shrimp sui mai, I didn't love the steamed BBQ pork bun 
-awesome green tea, you have to get it!
author: Shawn K.

description: We drove to this restaurant after seeing a long line for the Dim Sum place we originally planned on going to. The service was fast, the owner was very nice, and the food was great. My favorite dish, though not seen in the photos, was the 'Deep Fried Pork Puff.' It was savory and melted in my mouth. My sister who is a huge fan of soup dumplings loved her order of soup dumplings. All in all, each dish was thoroughly enjoyed and the bustly  atmosphere was reminiscent of an utterly enjoyable dim sum experience.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The food here has gone downhill since the last few times dining here. The Shanghai dumplings were way undercooked (pink pork meat) and the outside was gummy and like clay in my mouth. The vegetable gyoza/pot stickers were also gummy and very underdone, and the insides flavorless and a mix of random sodden vegetables that didn't pair well. The pork puffs had an incredibly fishy smell and taste to them inside and out, perhaps they were fried in the same oil as a seafood item. Many items we ordered this round were definitely inedible and we left much of it behind because we couldn't eat them nor were we at all interested in taking them home to-go. 

Service was touch and go. No air conditioning so the heat from the kitchen really fills the venue and makes it stuffy and uncomfortable. Floors were questionably clean. I'm sad that this was once featured in SF's Weekly Yelp and now it's really taken a nosedive.
author: Alison A.

description: Dim Sum Club has consistently gotten better over the past two years. Yup, five star worthy now. It used to be a little too oily (many of the dishes) but I feel like they took note and listened to customers - or got a new chef. Our last visit, we were so impressed with every single dish. What stood out: salt and pepper chicken wings (perfection) shanghai dumplings (perfect), pork chow mein (epic!) and onion pancakes (heaven!). I also like that they're friendly. Most dim sum experiences are impersonal - you order and there is no interaction with your server. Here they actually check in on you and ask you how you like everything. A little goes a long way. Yes, a Cow Hollow motel is a random location for dim sum, but heck, it works. And it's worth trekking to the area for if you are on a dim sum kick.
author: Meredith R.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese spots in SF, right on Van Ness. Don't judge it for being part of a motel! The food is pretty darn good. Parking can be an issue with being right on Van Ness, especially with all that construction going on with the lanes. We try to park a couple of blocks away and walk over. 

Food: They have congee! I ordered the pork and century egg congee, with ginger and scallion. Good sized portion (enough for two to share, or just be one hungry congee eater like me), and was served with the traditional side of deep fried dough cut into strips. I rather mine be whole, but it was fine. We also ordered the har gao (shrimp dumpling), and siu mai (shrimp + pork). Both delicious and fresh. The orange chicken was perfectly cooked, with a nice coating of sauce that wasn't overly sweet. The salt and pepper pork really should come in a entree size. Crisp and delectable. 

Service: The food does not all come out at one time. As with many Asian restaurants, dishes come out as they are cooked, and we're used to that. That does mean food is cooked to order, and everything was hot and fresh. Water glasses were kept filled, and we gave them a wave when the teapot needed refilling, but that was done quickly. 

Cost: We had SO much food. We clearly ordered too much. It was about $70 after tax and tip. And for 3 people with the amount of food we had, that was pretty decent.

Overall: Give it a try. Food is good, and the ambience was decent. Parking can be a bit of a pain, but if you're up for walking a couple of blocks, you'll be fine.
author: Shirley B.

description:
This restaurant seems to be geared toward non-Asians (probably because of the location), and because of that, prices are really high compared to other dim sum places. Siu mai for $6.25, are you forreal?! That better be the best darn siu mai I've ever had (spoiler alert - it's not). 

Buddha vegetarian noodle roll ($6.50) - full of veggies, including bamboo, carrots, and fungus. Noodle was thin and soft as it should be, while still being able to hold the contents of the roll without breaking apart. 
Chinese donut w/ noodle roll ($5.50) - came out looking a bit messy and deflated. The Chinese donut didn't taste like it had just come out, and so the whole thing was just kind of chewy. Didn't include sesame paste or sweet sauce, boo.
Pork & shrimp siu mai ($6.25) - looked good, decent size, juicy and tasted good too. But not so special that I can't get it elsewhere for a couple dollars cheaper. 
Steamed homemade dumpling ($5.50) - not personally a fan of this anywhere, but parents said it was good
Pan fried turnip cake ($5.00) - this was the best dish of the meal. Delicious and pan-fried beautifully with that nice crispy top!
Pan fried bean curd skin roll w/ shrimp ($6.75) - this was also fried very nicely so the bean curd was light and crispy. Very generous portions of shrimp inside.

One shocker is that tea is only $1 here, awesome! Menu doesn't have much variety outside of the standard dim sum items. They do have some rice lunch specials from 11am to 3pm. Service is good, restaurant is clean. Bathrooms are shared with a couple other office spaces in the back, but the door leading to it is broken, so you can't come back the same way and have to exit the building to go into the restaurant again. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back again because the prices are too expensive for food that isn't spectacular.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Dim Sum Club is a great restaurant downtown that knows how to prepare classic Chinese dishes.  We ordered an array of dishes including :

Shanghi Dumplings - These were great!
Fried Rice - Absolutely delicious' and would recommend
Chow Fun - Hot and tasty to eat!

I would not recommend the wonton soup, wontons were not that tasty but it was a huge portion meant for 2 or more people.
author: Alana B.

description: Really good spot for Chinese. Food came out quickly and the wait staff was attentive. Dumplings, calamari and pork buns were all really good. Egg rolls were decent. Prices were very fair for the quality. The hours are a little weird (closed at 8:50pm) but would definitely return if staying in the area again.
author: Al C.

description:
Have you ever known a restaurant that serves dim sum for dinner? Yeah, me neither. Despite the name, DSC does not serve dim sum all day! 

The dinner menu was instead a concoction of dishes conducive to family style dining. Food was pleasantly nice and had the "home cooked" flavor without being too oily or salty. The Chinese broccoli with garlic, pork strip rice noodles, and soft tofu were all solid choices.

You know what would make things really great? All day dim sum.
author: Cici T.

description:
Pros: no wait for tables, friendly staff/service, pleasant environment, not far out in chinatown or the richmond. Food comes out fast and some dishes are comparable to any good dim sum spot (the chinese broccoli, the congee). Great for large brunch groups who hate to wait. 

Cons: not the best dim sum in terms of quality. It is pretty obvious that a place like hong kong lounge has higher quality in certain items, such as the egg tarts. The choices are fair in range but again, its somewhat limited. Also the price is very high for dim sum, given the okay quality and small portions.

Recommend: the shrimp and peashoot leaf dumpling, the panfried mixed mushroom dumpling, chinese broccoli, the fried sesame balls.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
This review is only for take out. 

I actually wanted to dine in here but the employees seemed to say something like we could not due to a chef calling in sick. Their English was very poor but I was able to ask if we can get takeout. 

The prices are pretty steep but the quality is excellent. In addition, the interior is well kept so dining in is probably a nice experience. 

Rice Noodle with Fish- I usually order this with shrimp but I actually really enjoyed the fish filling! The fish was very flavorful and the noodles were soft and fresh. 

Siu Mai- Very tasty and meaty. On the smaller side. 

House Chow Mein- The noodles were cooked how I like, thin and crispy! Lots of toppings and different meats. The Chinese Broccoli was a surprise add instead of bok choy but it was tasty and soft, not too stringy either.
author: Jessica W.

description:
We came in and ordered food to go. The place was busy though not packed, so we were told we would have to wait 25 minutes. The food was ready in like 15 minutes.

I got the house pan-fried noodles. This had chicken, pork, shrimp, and squid in it with Chinese broccoli. The flavors were good, and I enjoyed the bits of crispy noodles as well as the parts that were soaked in sauce.

Don't miss the baked pork buns. These were the most delicious pork buns I've ever had, with a crisp outer layer and soft inside stuffed with sweet BBQ pork.
author: Ariana R.

description:
I'm super excited to have found Dim Sum Club because 1. It's not in Chinatown there was no wait on a Saturday morning and 2. The dim sum is LEGIT!

The location is pretty random on Van Ness in a hotel but once you enter it feels and looks like an authentic Chinese restaurant (aka no frills but hey, at least it's clean!)

Our group of two ordered way too much and the final verdict was:

Get:
-Shrimp dumpling
-Sticky rice in lotus leaf
-Steam Spare ribs
-Chicken Feet
-Turnip cake

Skip:
-Taro dumpling: too much mush, texture was off
-Shanghai dumpling: dough was too thick

House pan fried noodles were acceptable but other items were probably better. 
All in all a great find! Will be back when I feel that dim sum hankering!
author: Christina L.

description: Great noodle rolls, har gau, etc. A little more expensive than the east coast but I guess that is expected in this city.
author: Doven M.

description: Overcooked, not very tasty food, and difficult to digest. Not terrible, but would.not come back.
author: Federico P.

description: Not sure why this place is not more highly rated but love this sit down dim sum gem. Very family friendly accommodated a baby and 6 adults. Perfectly located for our party as it was a short stroll to a Fisherman's Wharf after lunch. We pretty much order everything including the staples shumai, pot stickers, bbq sweet pork pastries, taro, Singapore noodles, duck, beef... sesame seed balls and durian for dessert. Everything was fresh, tasty and yummy. The service was top rated and felt more like a family restaurant. Even though the food was not cheap it was well worth the value in my opinion for the quality and tastiness. Will definitely look to revisit in the near future.
author: Mark T B.

description: Excellent vegi noodle roll and pork bun. Def worth a try.
author: Chris M.

description:
Exactly what I was looking for. Greasy, hot, decent Chinese food.

I was really appreciative of the picture menu - perfect when you just don't have the brain to think about exactly what you want.

Boyfriend and I came here on a Wednesday evening, and were seated right away.
We ordered:
- Dim sum (har gow, siu mai) - made to order, which is rare for dim sum - came out steaming and delicious!
- Mixed stir-fry veggies - tasty
- Seafood chow mein - tasty, standard
- Mongolian beef - tasty, standard
- Two orders of white rice - nice and dry, the way I like it
Everything arrived at our table STEAMING hot. I was pleased. 

Everything was exactly like I expected and pretty yummy! A little on the pricier side for basic Chinese food; all this ran us $60 before tip, but not bad considering how many leftovers we took home. 

Would come again!
author: Vivian N.

description:
If you're looking for late night dim sum and you're in the Marina or Russian hill area, this is the spot. It might be the only late night dim sum open...

While the variety of true dim sum is limited (~12) they offer the typical dishes. 

My favorite was the dried scallop egg white fried rice. The chicken broccoli was unsurprisingly poor. Very dry meat and broccoli was over cooked. 

I came on Sunday night after Chinese New Years. Service was good and had friendly staff!
author: Jasper L.

description: We ordered soup dumplings as an appetizer. They were amazing. I got hot and sour soup. The portion is ginormous, definitely split this with 3 or 4 people. We also ordered the samosas. Everything really tasty, just terrible service.
author: Mandie C.

description: Last minute decision to come here for lunch. Overall we had a nice lunch, efficient service, good portions and decent pricing. There were 6 people total and we spent about $100 and all left pretty satisfied with leftovers.
author: Andrea I.

description: Got there at opening time to get a table and avoid long wait. Food comes out quickly and is good authentic Cantonese style dim sum (or "yum cha" as they call it in Australia). It was nice that they didn't try and push us out even though it was starting to get very busy.
author: Rozie W.

description:
This place is a solid three stars and, on a different day, may have been a four. It's not a bad place. The service was good - but don't try to ask the red flash (waitress) any more than one question per table visit - because by the time she answers the first, she is disappearing into the kitchen.

The food was quite good in a deep fried sort of way. 

We had our hearts set on a really good Dim Sum experience and, while it was a nice place with a good selection of Chinese food on the menu, we thought the Dim Sum was a little ordinary. However, we did arrive at night and Dim Sum is a daytime sort of thing. But, if you offer it at night, it should be just as good as at lunchtime.

Anyway, we had a nice time here despite being a little disappointed in the DS offerings. We would go again...but probably during the day.
author: David F.

description: Going by the name, you would think this is the place to be for dim sums. That's what we expected when we showed up here but we were slightly disappointed. Once we entered, the staff was least interested to take care of us. The jasmine tea is not complimentary here, just a note that we didn't realize in time. Eventually we got to placing our orders. The dim sums arrived but it was just average. We had better at other places and didn't feel this place lived up to our expectations.
author: Oly M.

description:
MEH, we were in the area on a weekday, felt bad there were no patrons.  We came, we ate, we left.  Who came up with the name "Dim Sum Club"?  Not too clever, did they even try?  

This definitely isn't Koi Palace or Mayflower, not even close!  The usual stuff like baos and noodle crepes were alright, nothing superb.  Some of the stuff tasted like it was frozen overnight and taken out the next morning to steam or cook.  The chicken feet was overcooked, and we mentioned it to our waitress.  She was nice enough to exchange it with something decent, which was the chive & pork dumplings.

Growing up in San Francisco's Outer Richmond, there are a plethora of authentic dim sum restaurants to choose from aka Hong Kong Lounges and Cantonese foods.  I've been too spoiled in the Avenues.  

Overall, wouldn't come back.  They also charge for tea per person.  If my mama knew that, she would slap me Madea-style!
author: Christine R.

description: I tried Dim Sum Club when I was visiting this neighborhood, and boy am I glad I did. This is better than all the dim sum restaurants I've had in SF Chinatown. It's much better than Yank Sing, which is the definition of tourist trap. The pricing here is a bit high but they make up for it in very satisfying portions--4 items are plenty for one person. Do yourself a favor and get their baked bbq bun, shrimp roll and, of course, the shrimp dumplings.
author: Carl W.

description: Oh yum! There is less than a handful of dim sum places in the city that I would consider great and Dim Sum Club is one of them. They don't have those ladies pushing the food carts around so the food is prepare by order which is actually better. The food comes out piping hot and super fresh. The siu mai is super juicy here! I highly recommend getting a few orders of that and the shrimp balls! Those perfectly fried meaty balls are huge! The biggest shrimp balls I ever had for dim sum.  LOL. It's a little pricey but the quality and service is worth it. I would definitely return and yes, I would recommend this place. Oh, and they take reservations so call ahead.
author: Judy V.

description: Been walking by this place for years but was always a little weirded out that it was on the ground floor of a motel. Finally tried it one day and it's now our go-to for when we are craving dim sum but too lazy to drive out to the Richmond. The place is a little old and dumpy but the food is pretty good and gets the job done. Service is fast and surprisingly friendly. Haven't waited more than 5-10 minutes for a table during peak times. You order via marking quantities on a piece of paper that has both English and Chinese.
author: Sarina Y.

description: Pretty good dim sum. Not too expensive, good service. Egg tarts were a little small, but everything else was a good size. Would go again!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Soooo, I'm going to be the odd duck in the bunch and rate Dim Sum Club two stars. After reading my co-workers compelling write-ups, I was extremely let down by the food quality and the service. 

What to know before dining:

1) The wait staff doesn't speak English.

2) The food is served piping hot. Don't make the same mistakes I made.

3) Yelp has placed a consumer alert on their page due to poor health inspection scores.

The only two items I thoroughly enjoyed were towards the end of our meal. Those being a Turnip Cake, which is most comparable to a hash brown, and the Salt & Pepper Squid. All the other items, primarily the dumplings, were not up to par for me. 

I left stuffed to the brim, but I have no reason to ever go back. Sorry, but you can kick me out of the Dim Sum Club!
author: Matthew C.

description:
Never had Dim Sum before, first time today 1/13/18
There was a menu to choose from ( I thought it was going cart to choose from) prices were reasonable. No pictures of food so you might want to google what you are ordering first or else you'll be surprised like us haha. Two of use ate for $41 we ordered about 4 different dishes. flavor of dishes were good. The food is some what greasy but good! Non-English speaking but you get an authentic fell
author: Yvonne m.

description: Great dumplings! Avoid the Shanghai dumpling- it wasn't as good as everything else. The shrimp dumplings were awesome!! Get the green tea- it makes the meal! The noodles were delicious!!
author: Gita K.

description: We happened upon this restaurant during our annual Christmas in the city day!  Delicious from beginning to end.  The pork buns were our unanimous favorite, but all of it was super yummy!  We'll definitely be back!
author: Denise R.

description:
Do NOT be fooled by the ratings. This place is extremely unprofessional & does not know how to tend to a customers dissatisfaction. 

Let's first start off with what I ordered:

SEAFOOD TOFU CLAY POT: Ok, so the title of this dish says it only has tofu and seafood right? WRONG. There was a bunch of beef & chicken along with the seafood and tofu. I am a pescatarian therefore I have a problem with beef and chicken in my food when the title of the meal obviously says only seafood and tofu. I asked the waitress if she got my order wrong and she kept saying, "Oh that comes with it too." I understand that she, along with everyone else at the restaurant does not speak English well so I gave them the benefit of the doubt. I asked if they're sure this is what I ordered and if they can double check. She constantly said yes beef and chicken come with this dish and I said but the title of the dish is seafood and tofu AND it was under the seafood options so why is there beef and chicken? Knowing that the other options were beef and chicken I specifically chose from the seafood menu for a reason.

I honestly don't wanna review the other items I ordered because those items were not all that great either.

CUSTOMER SERVICE: Whack. 

After all that happened they even asked us for a tip; they literally said, "Where's tip? Where's tip?" I always tip when I'm out to eat due to common courtesy however, definitely not in this case.
author: Phuong H.

description: Surprisingly decent Dim Sum in SF!  The place is filled with Chinese people so you know it's gotta be decent.
author: Byron L.

description: The BEST SHRIMP ROLL & STUFF MUSHROOM I have ever eaten. Compared to many ma y of the restaurants I've ever been too. They just melted in my mouth lol  everything else here are good also!! :)starting my 2018 right.
author: Hannle P.

description:
This place is a hidden gem a solid 4.5 stars!  Not fancy to look at but service is quick and the food is an excellent! 

We were saying goodbye to our son and daughter-in-law before heading out to Yosemite and wanted to fine a place for lunch at open at 11 AM near our hotel. The Dim Sum Club turned out to be a great choice!  We order 7-8 dishes, vegetable spring rolls, shrimp dumplings, Shanghai dumplings, fried tofu, steamed BBQ pork buns and sesame balls for dessert.  All of the food was good and the price exceptional considering we had eaten earlier that week at Yank Sing in the financial district and it was good but for the price I'd pick Dim Sum Club.  

Food - 5 stars food was very good and freshly prepared as we were in early and the kitchen started to crank out the food. 
Atmosphere- 3 stars not great but clean and in good shape.
Service - 4 stars Considering the time of day, they did great in getting our food out and keeping up with us on refills. 
Price - 5 stars  - We had a great early lunch for about $20 a piece before tip!
author: Ron P.

description:
We wanted something different than what we were getting with the ACRONYM events, and Chinese was chosen.  We Ubered up there and Ubered back.

The food was good....not great wow-a-riffic eyeballs rolling into the back of my head good.  But good solid food for a decent price.  I really enjoyed the dim sum sampler I got.  Everything was, of course fresh...something that I don't get very often in Reno.   I also loved the duck and the salt and pepper calamari.

I won't go with the old trope of looking at all the other Asians in the place to gauge the "authenticity".  It was also nice to have a nice "family" table to sit at, I know these tables aren't the best for floor space but they really do encourage great sharing and socializing over a meal.

And while good...I probably won't go back.  Because there are only so many meals I am going to be able to have in SF!
author: Robert S.

description: This restaurant was walking distance from my hotel. Very small restaurant with limited seating. Menu has various Chinese dishes along with dim sum offerings. We tried the shrimp dumplings which were steamed and delicious we tried the potstickers and bao. Dishes were cooked fresh to order in portions are very nicely sized for the price we had leftovers for breakfast the next morning the staff is nice and helpful ambience of the restaurant seems very small, but hey this is San Francisco. Parking is limited especially on Van Ness.
author: Rhondi S.

description: For selfish reasons, I almost want to keep this place a secret, but I must tell ya'll, they have a TON of vegan / vegetarian  options here! Honestly, dim sum can be quite scary for the Veggie eaters out there because mostly all things are packed with shrimp, pork, beef...etc. This is why I was super stoked eating here.  They even mark their menu items with a, "V," if it's vegetarian! Now this is a place that gets it! I'll always order their veggie dumplings which come in these green wrappers and stuffed with wood ear mushrooms, bamboo shoots, ginger, and cilantro.  Their salt and pepper tofu is probably one of the best in all the land...and they have have the most perfectly fried sesame balls....oh oh, and Ja Leung!! YESSSSS!!!  Clubbin at Dim Sum Club keeps me young. Love this spot!
author: Brian C.

description:
Take this review lightly, because after getting pretty hammered with #bosslady and fellow co-workers about an hour or two beforehand (and by hammered I mean this lightweight drank three tall beers), neither my tongue nor brain recalls much from this late night dim sum splurge sesh. But I'll tell you what I did remember: dim sum is some damn good drunk food. Oh, and that you have to these weird ascending steps in the back to get to the bathroom. 

Okay, okay. I remember other things:
*****
I. FOOD & DRINK
For drinks, they have your typical coke products, tea, and Tsingtao. Get a Tsingtao, because it's like the best worst-beer, ever. About the food:

*Har Gow: Pretty solid. The skin didn't stick to each other and the shrimp was deliciously juicy. I couldn't ask for more.

*Cheong Fun: My favorite - the shrimp crepe smothered in a sweet soy-sauce. I could eat this everyday of my life. I don't care that doing so would probably give me really high blood pressure.

*Shu Mai: Plump pork awesomeness. Why can't I eat this every time I'm tipsy? 

*Turnip Cakes: All right! Dip them in lots of soy sauce, and it's whatever...

*BBQ Pork Buns: I think they were pretty nice. I was pretty tired at this point.

*Xiaolongbao: Hmm, kind of thick with the dough. Juice was hot fire, though. 

**Deep Fried Pork Chive Dumplings: There were crumbs on my face and grease stains on my pants. So I would say good! 

**Singapore Street Noodles: Don't know why we got this, but it was all right. I wouldn't order it again.

So yeah, overall, the meal was pretty legit considering the circumstances. Definitely have this place on your radar if you're the type to inhale ice cream in the morning because YOLO. Lol.

II. SERVICE
Pretty fast! Not super friendly, but who cares. #dumplingsinmymouf

III. AMBIENCE/ DÉCOR
Nothing too fancy. When we went, there was an empty buffet bar and wine bottles out. Bathroom is in the back up the ascending stairs to the right. Somewhat clean. Lol.

IV. PRICES
Compared to other restaurants in The Bay, this establishment was pretty affordable!

V. OVERALL
So if you're in San Francisco...
-forget the greasy burger
-look away from that Korean BBQ taco (errr maybe not)
-and disregard the gigantic slice of pizza that's larger than your head, which could probably give you diabetes in one bite...

...because your stomach will thank you for journeying to the Russian Hill hood to check out Dim Sum Club. Holla!
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Rebecca and I stopped in earlier today. We chose this place by chance. I am glad we did.

We started with sticky rice and turnip cake. The sticky rice was warm and had great flavor. The turnip cake had wonderful flavor and texture. We then had shrimp and shumai; we enjoyed both. We ordered two orders of steamed buns. They were some of the best I have ever had. The dough was sweet, the filing warm and flavorful and the soy sauce enhanced the whole. 

I was surprised at the variety of reviews of this place. We could not have been happier with our meal, the service or the cleanliness  of the restaurant. We are very we stopped in.
author: Ronald A.

description:
When my buddy suggested we go grab dim sum for lunch yesterday, I was super stoked because I hadn't had it in a while. He mentioned that it was located inside a hotel and it's a "hidden gem" mostly because of it's proximity to where we both live. I was super intrigued because I have a pretty good handle on dim sum spots in SF (none of which I've had outside of the normal dim sum neighborhoods). 

Annnnnnnyyyywaaaaayyyy. We were greeted by a friendly host and the servers were super nice. That's not typical for most dim sum spots, so props to the staff for that. I was surprised to see the prices so high for dim sum, especially at lunch. I'd say the average per item was just over $5, which may not seem high, but in the world of dim sum is quite pricey. 

We ordered a number of dishes (see pictures) and they were all just ok. Everything felt a bit greasy, the fillings heavy and nothing really wowed me. Perhaps it was because my expectations had been built up, perhaps it just wasn't my style. Who knows. I will say that the duck was pretty damn good and the skin super crispy.

All in all, it's a passible spot if you live in the area. However, I would suggest making the trek to the outer richmond district to find the legit dim sum spots in SF.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
We went for dinner, not for weekend dim sum. The dim sum selection is a lot smaller in the evening; we got the $10 dim sum sampler, which was a small but tasty selection. I was impressed by the texture of the pork bun, and the skins of the har gaw were decently thin. I'd be interested in coming back for weekend dim sum for sure! We also got the bbq pork noodles, which were good but not anything spectacular. 

The food and price would probably be 4 stars, but the restaurant had a serious fruit fly problems. Luckily none were in the food, but they were zooming around the dim sum and noodles the whole time...
author: Hali M.

description: Food is great not salty. Dimsum was perfectly cook. Parking was bit issue. But everything is good
author: Dennis C.

description:
The Dim Sum Club was another place  highly recommended to me by my Yelp Community Director.  We had an enjoyable, delicious dinner here.  If you're looking for a nice sit-down restaurant for dim sum this is your place. Finding it was a little challenging.  It's on the first floor in the middle of a multi-story building.  I didn't realize until I researched it later that it is on the ground floor of a hotel! 

There is ample seating available.  We told them we might have some people joining us later and they were happy to seat us at a table that could accommodate them. Part of the fun of a place like this is trying many different dishes.  We each ordered individually but shared with each other.  One unexpected bonus was that the extremely friendly gentleman who welcomed us to the restaurant rolled a cart over to the table and cut the duck into bite sized pieces to put into buns.  It was interesting getting to watch that. Everything I ate was quite good.  The pork potstickers that I ordered were my favorite and a sesame ball was a great way to finish the meal (thanks Robert!).

As much as I enjoyed the food I did have some complaints.  The glasses for water they give you are the size of a thimble, which is a nightmare for me because I tend to drink a lot while I'm eating. I had to flag down our poor waitress at least three times for more water.  When I was ordering I asked for separate checks and that was met with resistance. When the bill came we asked if they could just divide it by four and that was refused also.  They would only divide it in two. Weird but definitely not show stoppers for coming back for more great food from the Dim Sum Club!
author: Chris W.

description:
"Poor food safety alert" was what we saw on Yelp when reading the reviews on this place. I love mom and pop shops so that didn't deter me from wanting to try it. 

Service was okay, it wasn't busy. 

What we ordered:

Salt n pepper calamari: it had good flavor, tender, not too salty and lots of jalapeños which I loved. 

X.O. Turnip cakes: this was yummy. A twist on the regular cakes, deep fried to perfection. The mister is not a fan of turnip cakes anytime I order it at dim sum but this he actually enjoyed. 

Shrimp rolls: meh, nothing special. Same like every where else.

Pork and shrimp Sui Mai: these were bigger than the norm I've seen around town. It was really juicy and had huge chunks of shrimp it in. The only thing I still can't wrap my head around was its sweetness. At first I thought ok, maybe it's the shrimp...but the more I ate it, it definitely was not the shrimp. I dunno....

Chicken feet: I have been craving this for a while and was looking forward to it. This however was a huge let down. It too was sweet....really sweet, like too much sugar or something. It was almost inedible. 

Maybe this place really like their food sweet.
author: Tuyet N.

description:
This dim sum place is not bad. I would come back again but I don't think I would put this in my favorite dim sum places.

One of my favorite dishes the beef rice noodle roll had cilantro in it. I've gotten this dish plenty of times at other dim places and didn't have this problem. I took one bite and was saddened by the taste.

Their other dishes weren't bad. I liked their eggplant dish. The sauce was really savory. I thought the Shanghai dumplings were decent as well.

Decent food, but still felt like something was missing though. They also don't bring the carts but have the menu for you to choose from.
author: Danielle C.

description:
I don't even want to tips this restaurant. The food is okay but their service at night is very poor.
Customer experience: BAD.
author: Lê H.

description: Ate here on my last visit to San Francisco's Chinatown, I'm going to save you the trouble of coming here for dim sum, the name can be deceiving. This is not a true dim sum restaurant, this is a Chinese American food restaurant.  Don't expect traditional Chinese, Cantonese, Hunan, or etc.... it's Americanized.  The service was ok, water drinking glasses are super small, they give you kid size water glasses, I mean come on.  Had the Mongolian beef stir fry, it was greasy, really small portions for the price you're paying.  I would say in a pinch this place is ok.
author: Vic C.

description:
Dear Mr. Lunchon,

We accept the fact that we had to sacrifice a whole Wednesday in dimsumtion for whatever it was we did right.

But we think you're hangry to make us write an essay telling you what we think we eat. You order us as you want to order us: in the dimmest terms, in the most summent definitions.

But what we found out is that each dish of us is a CRISPY DUCK brain...

And a PORK NOODLE ROLL athlete...

And a SHRIMP CHIVE DUMPLINGS basketcase...

A CURD SKIN BEEF BALLS princess...

And a smooth SPARE RIB NOODLE ROLL criminal.

Does that answer your DURIAN PUFFS?

Sincerely yours,

The Breakfast Dim Sum Club
author: Dan B.

description: After our meal, my sister had wrote a $0 for the tip part on the check because she was going to give cash. Before my sister was even able to pull out her cash, the lady who was checking us out had the nerve to say "excuse me" and point at the $0 amount on the tip. RUDEEEEEEEEEE! I would have not left a tip!!!!! But knowing how nice my sister was she still did. Bitch pleaseeee.
author: Newzong Y.

description:
#19/2016

I was in the mood for dim sum but I was *not going to head to Chinatown on market day (I've done that before, madness), I didn't feel like getting it "to go" and heading home.

After all, isn't the fun of dim sum eating it piping hot, fresh from the steam cart?

While you won't get the rolling steam cart experience here- you tick off your own selections on a thin, pink paper menu- you'll get very good service & probably eat a little less since those tempting little baskets won't constantly be passing you by.

My little boy and I bounced around the menu getting the BBQ pork noodle roll, Won Ton soup (outstanding!), XLB (Shanghai soup dumplings), Shrimp & chive dumplings, pork siu mai, har gao, pineapple baked buns, an entree (huge portion!) beef and rice with egg

(raw egg poured over the top of this huge steaming bowl of beef & rice, simply stir in).

For those hard core foodies, they have deep fried durian dumplings. I bet you haven't seen these at Yank Sing, nope!

The service is crisp, quick and friendly, the restaurant looks very clean and the dishes are very good. Most of the clientele are Chinese, always a great sign.

For a sit down, dim sum experience without breaking the bank, I highly recommend Dim Sum Club.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Sadly, after years of enjoying Dim Sum Club as my go to place, and being on friendly terms with the owner, I can no longer recommend it. This isn't one bad experience or a fluke. Over time ingredient quality has gone down, prices up, portions smaller, it seems like corners are being cut, and the bottom line execution and taste of the dishes isn't what it used to be. The repeated bad health inspections point to the same thing... the thrill is gone. Sorry.
author: Gil S.

description:
Who'd have thought you could find good dim sum in a motel? Yes indeed, it's in the DaVinci Villa at Van Ness and Filbert, and at first, I scratched my head wondering how good could it possibly be? Y'see, I've been on a bit of a hunt for good soup dumplings ever since Jamie W. and I returned from Shanghai a few weeks ago where we had what we think were the best ones at a place called Din Tai Fung. It's ironically part of a Taiwanese-based international chain, but they treat dumplings like little pieces of culinary art complete with step-by-step instructions on how to eat them. Even their menu was gorgeous and inviting.

Not so much here. It's the standard pink sheet with the checklist (photo: http://bit.ly/1OwfNMF) and gratefully no rolling carts like at Yank Sing where I always end up getting stuff I had no intention of eating. Alas, we still ate pretty heartily starting with a $6.95 bowl of Wonton Soup since it was too cold outside not to. It was good with a lighter broth and plenty of Chinese broccoli (photo: http://bit.ly/1VuwOMW). Jamie ordered the $4.50 quartet of Pan Fried Pot Stickers, and they were stellar, meaty with the right amount of crust and no need for the sweet sipping sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1kxjvxL). I decided on the $5.75 BBQ Pork Noodle Roll just because I like the softer texture (photo: http://bit.ly/1MKmsBQ).

Jamie enjoyed the pork filling a lot since they use liberal chunks of chashu. Of course, we needed to try the $7.50 Shanghai Dumplings because that was our primary reason for being there. Served in the traditional bamboo steam basket, the half-dozen dumplings were plump with broth, so it was a good thing we were trained so well in Shanghai on how to eat them lest we lose all the soup on our shirts (photo: http://bit.ly/1YV6XOw). We followed those up with a $4.25 basket of Vegetarian Dumplings which of course came in green wrappers, but they were surprisingly savory with mushrooms giving good unami flavor (photo: http://bit.ly/1SpIMYA). Methinks we'll be coming back to this motel.

FOOD - 4 stars...surprisingly good dumplings in a most unlikely place
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...fairly generic inside but plenty of booths and tables for large groups
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...speedy and friendly enough
TOTAL - 4 stars...if you can't make it to Shanghai, this'll do
author: Ed U.

description: Great food served hot and fast! As far as Dim Sum platter goes it is the best I have had. I'm going to go as far as saying this Chinese Dim Sum is as good as it gets! I cannot wait to return, I visited yesterday and I cannot stop thinking about that Dim Sum Platter.
author: Michael P.

description: Great food.  Enjoyed the sesame balls dumplings eggplant and noodle rolls.  Food came out quick and hot.  Staff was not friendly however did their job efficiently.  Would go back. Left with a happy belly.
author: Dena L.

description:
I've had dim sum in Los Angeles and Monterey Park, two places that know how to do dim sum.

The food here was on par with the best!

The har gow was tender, not gooey. And the shrimp was flavorful. We mistakenly ordered boiled spare ribs and discovered they were delicious!

The salt and pepper calamari was especially tasty with just a squeeze of lemon. 

Light and fluffy steamed buns for the BBQ pork filled me up too much for the salted egg dessert, but now as I'm home writing this, I sure would love to have one.

The atmosphere is casual, the service friendly and the food, mmmmmm, mmmmm, good!
author: Patty H.

description: This place isn't great but I will say I keep coming back for the hot and sour soup. The one with dumplings is so good! Everything else is okay.
author: Tina L.

description:
A dim sum place in RUSSIAN HILL/MARINA?! That is amazing! And the fact that it is actually pretty good. I crave for dim sum once in a while but I don't want to travel to Chinatown. So happy there is one near me now. 

You can make reservation which that is awesome. The staff is nice and friendly.

My favorite dim sum is their X.O turnip cake and chicken wings (for lazy people, because they take out the bone for you). Their main dishes, such as noodles are really good, favorite is their seafood crispy noodle.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Tried this for lunch and was frankly surprised and pleased by so many things. It's a very clean and open atmosphere with kind, attentive service. I looked for the $10 dim sum sampler but it wasn't on the menu. My guess is that it's a goner. 

The shu mai pork and shrimp filled dumplings were juicy and well seasoned. They really were supple and fresh. That was the first dish that came pretty quickly. Ordered a small cup of steamed rice too. The salt and pepper chicken wings were delicious but they weren't glazed or dry flavored too much. The fresh scallions and jalapeño peppers on top were a nice and welcome touch. I accidentally ordered the pan fried turnip cakes but they weren't too bad. I liked the texture--firm but still moist too. The pan fried pot stickers --what I really meant to order--arrived just at the end, plump and sweaty a bit. Glad I always had the soy sauce and chile oil sauce for me to dip in the whole time. The sauce that came with -- well, it didn't have much flavor. This place is a great find.
author: Alfonso L.

description: Good food but they don't do carts which is always fun. Location is good and noise is not too bad.
author: Emile K.

description: Classic Chinese dim sum nothing fancy but delicious food & fast service at a reasonable price.  I don't think they have carts though we ordered off the menu which is becoming more standard for dim sum restaurants these days.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Haven't been to that many dim sum places in SF but this was one pretty good (and my friends who do go to a lot also agreed) 

We ordered pork buns (steamed and baked - baked was amazing), shrimp dumplings, porridge with century egg, pork rice and egg dish, Peking duck, seafood pancake, sticky rice balls.
author: Laura D.

description:
Yum dim sum! 

Traditionally a breakfast thing, I was happy Yelp helped us find a spot open for dinner. I was also thrilled to be dining with a couple people that knew exactly what to order, and in the right language! 

PRO TIP: Wait for everything to cool off before you start feasting. NO MATTER HOW HUNGRY YOU ARE. There's nothing more painful than a boiling hot soup dumpling bursting in your mouth and running down your throat. You've been warned. 

Now that that's out of the way, I enjoyed everything we tried. From the fried dumplings and steamed pork buns, to the shrimp siu mai and turnip cake (first time!). The food came out quick and our table kept eating and eating until we almost had to be rolled out. We got a little ambitious and also ordered some noodle dishes at the end. Those were good too!

I would definitely recommend Dim Sum Club for a super casual and enjoyable dim sum experience! It's best with more than a couple people so you can order lots and share among the table.
author: Cassie P.

description: All the dim sum here is good and on the level.  Try the shanghai steamed dumplings and shrimp dumplings.  They are fantastic.
author: Michael C.

description: This is my first one star review. At first, I went to the restaurant because it had good reviews, but it turned out to be the most disgusting experience that I have ever experienced at a restaurant. I almost swallowed plastic pieces that was inside the stuffed mushroom I ordered. One plastic piece that I pulled out of my mouth was bigger than a quarter, and the second piece was the size of a nickel. The food tasted alright and when I told the waitress about the stuffed mushroom, she cancelled the order; however, it is not worth it. I don't recommend the place.
author: Helena L.

description: We came here for dinner tonight.  Order Dim Sum dishes and pan fried noodle.  I was pleasantly surprised that they were willing to make pork and bean sprout pan fried noodle dish since it wasn't on the menu.  We then ordered dumpling (very good and homemade), ha gow, siu mai and steam pork bun.  Everything was delicious and they don't use MSG like other places.  Service was great!  Definitely coming back here again.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Most reviews on Yelp are for the dim sum served here during the day.  A few reviews positively mention dim sum for dinner, failing to note that at dinner the dim sum menu is greatly abbreviated.  Most of the dishes offered are for larger plates at a heftier tab.  At my dinner this past Sunday evening I was alone in the restaurant for some of my meal and only a single couple showed up throughout the course of my meal.  But service was spot on, caring, and all of the food arrived piping hot.

An appetizer of shiu mai was just OK.  There were four shiu mai to the order and each was somewhat smaller than those I have had at other places and surmounted by a whole individual shrimp.  Yet the taste of these was pallid, not bad mind you, but not at all bright.

Next up was lemon chicken, a main course priced at 13.95.  Actually, this was quite good as the white meat chicken wasn't overly breaded and there was plenty of chicken on the plate.  And the too abundant lemon sauce wasn't much too sweet.  This would be a good plate to share.

I finished my meal with potstickers.  This plate of dim sum was only OK as the wrapper was too thick and not well filled with pork.  

So the surprise of my visit was that at dinner the main courses seemed better prepared and a better bargain than the vaunted dim sum so positively commented upon most notably for lunch.
author: David D.

description:
Yes! A spot that serves Dim Sum for dinner! Apparently they are really hard to find. No idea why, it makes for a delicious dinner!! 

We called ahead for a party of 8 at 7:30pm and when we arrived, there wasn't even a wait so win win for sure. This is not a fancy spot but the staff was nice and the food was delicious. Beer and wine only.

Luckily I was with two dim sum experts so I just sat back and ate what was put in front of me! It came out HOT! I mean really hot. I had to wrestle with desire and put some serious patience into waiting to try each piece.  

Everything I tried was delicious. My favorites were the Siu Mai, Steamed BBQ Pork Bun and the Pan Fried Shrimp & Chives Dumpling. 

Overall our group left stuff, happy and craving more Dim Sum for days. =) 

One tip for the business: lazy Susan in the middle of the table so you can share the dishes better.
author: Colleen B.

description: Mediocre dim sum. Nothing really stands out here, just your typical msg filled unfresh chinese dim sum. Unfriendly service. Long wait. Prices are not cheap either, would not come back.
author: Janelle W.

description:
After reading reviews good and bad, including a warning for a low food hygiene score, we went anyway. DSC has the usual 2-sided dim sum checklist, with the usual suspects as well as some larger dishes (including congee). 

The overall impression can be summed up thusly: everything that came to the table was piping hot, fresh, and very tasty. Tea refills were instant and prompt. This is not the cheapest place, not the most expensive either. The plates are perhaps a little more generous than I usually see.

We say check it out.
author: Torgeir H.

description:
I am a fan of any restaurant that offers dim sum any time of the day!

Traveling with an Asian parent (hi mom!) means that we need to eat Chinese food Every. Single. Day. This makes my life difficult as I am supposed to pick all of the restaurants. Dim Sum Club saved my butt by being a reasonably close Chinese restaurant with decent ratings AND lived up to the hype with solid food. 

Food: My favorites were the crystal shrimp dumplings. The beef with broccoli was not greasy and generously portioned. The seafood with tofu was generously portioned and tasty but IMO needed more seafood and less tofu. The rice was apparently very good according to mom. My siblings loved the Shang Hai-style steamed baozi. The duck was pretty standard. 

Conclusion: a decently authentic Chinese joint in a non-Chinatown area of SF that won the Chinese Mother Seal of Approval. If you've ever dined with an Asian mother, you should know that they disapprove of almost everything.
author: Diya L.

description:
Dim Sum Club has gone down since the first time I was here shortly after they opened in 2014. Seems like they've gotten lazy and don't take pride in their work or food at all. 

When I approached the door, the signs all said closed even though they were clearly open. Fruit flies were rampant at our table, with one flying by every few seconds. After we finished our meal, two of them promptly landed on our plates and started feasting away. Worst of all, the soup in the Shanghai dumplings was way too hot and actually burned my lip, causing a blister that turned a dark color and peeled off a couple days later. That type of disaster should only happen at a place like McDonald's, but really shouldn't happen anywhere. They were soupy though, I'll give them that. 

Fried taro balls didn't have enough crispy fried parts and tasted room temperature. This place isn't cheap either. It was $5.75 for the rice rolls for and $7.75 just for porridge (rice and water). That's almost like daylight robbery, but I guess that's most of SF.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Excellent food. We had a mix of Dim Sum and Chinese fair. We found the Dim Sum (containing veggies, pork, and shrimp) to be very fresh and succulent. To our surprise when the Chinese food came out we were also delighted by the freshness and flavores. Dynamic and savory dishes without being drenched in sauces. Highly recommend the Chilli Chicken and a String Bean dish. 
Service leaves much to be disired but nothing really bad happened and the staff is smily and warm.
author: Leo R.

description:
We came here on a friend's recommendation and we were so glad we did...dim sum is delicious and the service is friendly and quick. 
We were the second table seated at 11:30 am. By 12:30 pm there were two large tables of nine and six, and five more 2-tops.
The dim sum is made to order, served hot and fresh, generous portions, and tasty.
Two of us ordered the steamed spareribs with black beans, har gao, deep fried taro dumplings, turnip cakes, curry samosas, bacon shrimp, and beef noodle rolls. Hot tea.  $50 includes tax and tip.
Street parking is easy.
We'll return for more delicious dim sum.  I am curious about the $10.95 lunch plates with rice.
author: Geri S.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Dim Sum Club for the following reasons:
+ No wait if you come before 11:30am. It's not huge, but it's less popular than other dim sum places. By noon, though, there was a line out the door.
+ The food comes out immediately.
+ Friendly service. They actually smiled and refilled our waters.
+ The food isn't as greasy as other places.
+ The buns (char siu and pineapple) are so tasty here!

Overall, an excellent choice for dim sum if you don't want to to wait or trek to Chinatown or Inner Richmond. There are only a few tables for larger groups (6+), which I found a bit strange, but that means more seating for groups of 2-4.
author: Valerie L.

description:
TL;DR - I've never food coma-ed so hard from dim sum... and not in a good way.

Ok. Maybe it was an off morning? Or I just ordered the wrong things. But regardless, I left feeling queasy and sad. 

We got the shu mai, shrimp dumplings, steamed bbq pork buns, golden yolk buns, xlb, and the beef roll with the rice noodle. 

GREASE. Everything was greasy and overly salty. The char siu in the pork buns was so sad... there was more gelatinous sugar "sauce" than actual char siu. The shrimp dumplings didn't have nice big pieces of shrimp... but more of like... a paste. 

But I think the most disappointing was the XLB (xiao long bao, shanghai dumpling, whatever you wanna call it.) The soup was not even flavoured well. Instead of a nice mix of soup and filling, the filling was almost... overcooked? You know, when meat gets too cooked and starts to crumble. Imagine dry, overcooked meat in greasy soup and you've pretty much got an idea of what this xlb was like.

Maybe my standards are too high, but even dollar dim sum over in china town beats this place. If you're going to charge legit dim sim prices, please deliver sit-down dim sum quality food. This place? Overpriced and mostly trying to appeal to tourists. (which is shocking because the dollar dim sum in chinatown is better than this place.)
author: Crystal Z.

description: Good, not spectacular. I would recommend for good Chinese but not as much for dim sum. We had the shrimp dumplings which were tasty but we enjoyed the "entrees" more. Sesame chicken, soy sauce show mein and vegetable egg rolls. All pretty tasty.
author: Manda P.

description:
I really wanted to give this place credit. The food is good, but I just can't not share my experience.

We arrived around 2:45 which is 15 minutes before the closing time but they were nice enough to seat us. They gave polite service when serving my older relative who had a lot of demands and is very challenging to deal with. The food came quick, too. 

I chowed down my House Pan Fried Rice and was halfway done with my meal when I flipped over a piece of chicken and FOUND DEAD FLIES on it. I was too much of a hurry to actually look at my food earlier; what a huge regret.

There were flies swarming everywhere! Should have known there would be many in the food. A fly landed on my spoon and as I tried to shoo it away, it flew into my soup! The fly committed suicide onto my food! 

At first I assumed there was just dirt on the napkins they gave us but when I looked closely, it was a dead fly. Ugh, the thought that I was eating flies this whole time is revolting! 

The workers were on their lunch but we called them over to tell them what we saw. They cancelled the order that contained the flies but we lost our appetite and didn't finish the rest of our food. 

The waitress told us that they had a fly problem and abruptly brushed off a 'sorry.'
author: Murphy S.

description: YUUUUUUM. Visited this place for lunch and appreciated how clean and cool (temperature-wise) it was. The servers were very friendly and patient. We greatly enjoyed their lo mein - tasted like the noodles were homemade. We also got steamed bbq pork buns, dumplings, and rice wrapped in lotus leaves. All of which we enjoyed - everything was delicious. We would definitely come back if we were ever in town.
author: Sarah M.

description: Awesome little Chinese joint. You have to take it for what it is, it's cheap but delicious and nothing more. Nice service too compared to other Chinese restaurants!
author: VZ D.

description:
Food: Best dim sum I've found so far, including places in Chinatown like Dol Ho and Lai Hong.

Service: Prompt and to the point. Sometimes you get items in an unexpected order, but I guess they bring everything as soon as it's ready.

Atmosphere: Had to dock a star for a serious fruit fly infestation. Got to the point where both of us were swatting as we ate to avoid adding extra protein to our diets.

Price: Fair.

Highlights: Baked pork bun, sponge cake, and pan-fried turnip cake.
author: Ananya M.

description:
Came here during lunch with group of co-workers while we were doing LEAN Six Sigma training next door at the hotel.
We ordered a mountain load of food and everything was actually really good.
author: Linda W.

description: Update: YIKES!  Found an insect/small roach in our soup AND the duck meat was clearly rotten, too soft, and inedible on the first bite.  Sent both dishes back.  We made the mistake of eating the other couple of dishes before leaving, and felt pretty queasy afterwards.  Had been to this restaurant many times and had enjoyed the food in the past, YET always wondered why the health score was so low (below 70, which is the cutoff).  For a while, there used to be a "health warning" on Yelp.  Now, we finally and clearly know why.  They must have pretty poor practices and hygiene habits for keeping food safe and clear of pests.  To their credit, they have very friendly service, and they waitress was very apologetic, so they deserve a star just for that.  But until they address the health and safety issues: BEWARE!!!
author: candide o.

description:
By far my favorite dim sum restaurant in San Francisco for several reasons:

1) The food is bomb. And I'm talking about every single dish, from the Shanghai dumplings to the sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves.

2) There is never a line. The location is so unusual for a Chinese restaurant (on S Van Ness Ave in Russian Hill) that most people probably don't give it a second glance... which only works to our benefit ;-)

3) Prices are higher than what you'd be paying in Chinatown, but again well worth it for the convenience.

4) Service is amazing. One time my boyfriend and I came in at 2:55pm, not realizing they close at 3pm, and the manager came over to us to explain the situation. It was obvious he cared about his employees yet did not want to deny us food, and he said he would make an exception for us, with a smile on his face all the while. I see him every time I come back and always feel well taken care of.

Prior to discovering Dim Sum Club, scheduling a time to eat dim sum was always such an ordeal... we'd have to mentally prepare ourselves for long lines and wait times. Now it's just a matter of walking in and out with our bellies full!
author: Tiffany W.

description: Just ate there one week ago and the place is clean and the food is delicious good. The price is higher due to available in the area but worth it. Be careful not to over order but again you can have a late snack! Noodle dishes are very tasty and cook  just right.
author: LL Y.

description:
Want dim sum, but don't want to drive to Sunset/Richmond? AND you don't want to wait around forever because you're impatient and/or too hungry?  Solution: Dim Sum Club!  

Name and location may make you question the authenticity and quality of the food, but don't doubt!  All the staple dim sum dishes are available and while they don't do the dim sum carts, service is fast and the food comes out fresh!
author: Janel C.

description:
Dim sum club has a small menu, but is still pretty good. Perhaps the best part about it was that it was busy on the Sunday around noon, but we still didn't have to wait. I really hate having to wait 90+ minutes for a table at some of the better dimsum places on weekends.

Everything that we ordered was pretty good. in particular, the ha gow and xiao long bow were standouts. Unfortunately, there weren't any Chinese ladies pushing carts around, since you order by checking off items on the menu, but at least everything was delivered to our table within 10 minutes, and everything was piping hot and fresh.

Definitely will come back again when I want a sitdown dimsum experience, and I don't wait to wait an hour.
author: Allen T.

description:
In my limited Dim Sum eating experience, DSC is pretty solid. My boyfriend and I stumbled on this place yesterday and I had heard good things so we decided to give it a shot. There was (surprisingly?) no wait on a Sunday at noon and we were seated promptly.

Now, this isn't a cart Dim Sum place. They give you a paper menu and you mark down what you want and how many orders. The waitresses come around and make a note of what you ordered. I think we waited about 10 minutes from when the waitress came around until our first dish arrived. Between the two of us, we had:

-Steamed BBQ Pork Buns: We agree that THESE ARE THE BEST WE HAVE EVER HAD. Keep in mind, neither of us are very experienced in our Dim Sum cuisine so its possible that these are actually average and we just have eaten worse. Either way-we really enjoyed them!

-Steamed Spare Ribs: These were ok. We ordered these to try something new and while they tasted good, they were difficult to eat. I probably just am not a fan of this dish in general rather than DSC's execution

-Steamed Homemade Dumpling: Really good and had a bit of a kick! I am not sure what these are filled with, but I am pretty sure there is shrimp and pork from what I could see. These were really big and generous.

-Sticky Rice in Lotus Leaf: Standard but enjoyable. 

For these 4 dishes, with tax, it was $18.50 which is reasonable. The one thing we didn't like is that they charge for tea which I have only seen at Yank Sing. This is a very minor complaint as the charge was only $1/person but it did sway us not to order it.

Overall, I would come back if I were in the area. I have had better Dim Sum in SF but this was a solid option and for no wait and for how organized and clean this place is, I cannot complain.
author: Carrie W.

description:
This was somewhat disappointing for me.  It could be because we ordered too many deep fried items.  

Pros - 
The seafood jook was very good.  Plenty of whole shrimp.
The steamed Ha Gow dumpling was good.  Plenty of shrimp
The shrimp stuffed mushroom was good.

Cons -
The Chinese broccoli was overlooked.   No snap at all.
The deep fried taro tasted old and smelly.
The other fried items were oily & greasy like the bean curd and minced pork dumpling.
The Chinese donut that went with the jook was oily & greasy.  
The chicken feet was over steamed.

Anything shrimp related was good.  Anything deep fried was oily & greasy.

I don't think I'll be back.
author: Shirley N.

description:
My parents live in Nob Hill and our choices for dim sum are either go to Chinatown or drive to Richmond for dim sum. 

This place is walkable for us and has decent dim sum. We never have to wait super long for a table, we are always seated right away even though this place is pretty tiny.

This place def hits the dim sum spot but only thing is that it's pretty pricey compared to CT and Richmond. My family and I've only been here three times but each time we racked up a bill of over $100, where as elsewhere we eat for less than $100 for 6 people. 

Definitely a place to try out once but there's really nothing special that you can't get elsewhere for cheaper.
author: Kelly L.

description:
I know its not your typical dim sum dish but, bacon wrapped shrimp was really tasty.
Dishes exceeded my expectations.
author: Dorothy Y.

description:
Great spot for dim sum without the hassle and crowds of Chinatown.  The food is not as heavily salted as other spots but the taste and textures are much cleaner (no guessing whether or not your dumplings contain actual meat).  They also have an open kitchen so you can watch some of the action and you will notice that most of the things you order don't get cooked until your order goes in, so dumplings come out hot and juicy!

Prices are higher than what you'd get at cheaper places ~$5 per order for most items but the quality is there, the service is excellent, and the street parking is free!
author: Eric N.

description: Amazing service, and really quick food! Recommend the Thai noodles and the dim sum is only available for lunch btw. (Apparently that's well known)
author: Saideh H.

description: Amazing food with very attentive service. The inside was also a lot cleaner than some of the other dim sum restaurants in the city. I'll definitely be back.
author: Kevin C.

description:
There's a reason this place has no line out the door and isn't stuffed with large Asian families and Chinese grandpas on a Sunday morning. This is the kind of dim sum place you go to if you're new to dim sum, want English menus, and have never experienced Chinese food in the Richmond.

Food:
1) Chinese Donut Wrapped in Rice Roll
The donut was (surprisingly) not over-fried, but the texture of the rice roll was not right at all. It was dense, bland, and didn't have the bounce and chewiness of good rice rolls. Also, this dish did not come with the traditional peanut sauce and sweet sauce that is served at every other dim sum place.

2) Vegetarian Dumplings
Bland. Tasted like eating water. Don't get them.

3) Shanghai Soup Dumplings
My friend is a XiaoLongBao aficionado, and he rated these dumplings a thumbs down, 2/5. The soup was too tart and the skin was too thick and sticky. If you want good XLB, go to Shanghai Dumpling King instead :)

4) Salted Egg Yolk Custard Buns
The only good dish we ordered! Just the right amount of saltiness, and the custard was oozing out like a proper salted egg yolk bun (unlike an egg custard bun). I was pleasantly surprised!

Service was good, but since only 1 out of 4 dishes was tasty, this place gets 2 stars from me.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Pretty standard in terms of food and price. Parking is available and the tables turn pretty quickly so usually no wait.
author: Eddie T.

description: We come here specifically for the baked pork buns and I'm sad that it's not the same anymore. The buns look completely different, smaller in size, and are just like any other pork buns from other places. The other dim sum items are just whatever to me and aren't much of a difference compared to other places. I don't think I'll be coming here next time.
author: Maggie W.

description:
The food here was amazing, hot fast and full of flavor. AND for $32 me and my hubby got filled up! I was a little cautious because of a less than desirable experience at the highly over priced and publicized Yank Sing place we had been to just a few days ago. 
Service was a little shaky at first, then our waitress disappeared and a more "seasoned" lady appeared and rocked the service.  I would highly recommend this place for good Dim Sum especially the Deep Fried Taro Dumpling!
The only thing missing are the steam carts, you order by form but that's fine because the food was so good.
author: Stephen F.

description: Fewer places to go now in Chinatown, this place serve traditional dim sum Hong Kong style.
author: Catalina W.

description:
Best chicken wings I have ever had. The poultry is filleted from the bone and the result is the most crispy delightful taste you will ever experience. The spare ribs, Shanghai dumplings, steamed pork bun and pork and shrimp sui mai are a must!!

The service is friendly and attentive, they keep open late past closing to accommodate their customers. This is the best restaurant and service I have found in San Francisco a must must try!!
author: Gabriel O.

description: Definitely not your cheap Chinatown dimsum place, but I'm certainly a fan! Came right when it opened on a Sunday, so there was no line. Service was really quick. Food was really fresh, and I love how the shui mai and shrimp dumplings are very plump and juicy. Their portions are smaller than other dim sum I've had, but the quality is really good! Averaged about $30 per person.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Great food!  We loved every single dish we ordered (dumplings, potstickers, satay beef, soy sauce chow mein).  Even my 6 year old who refuses to try Chinese food, tried the noodles and loved them.  Definitely recommend this for a delicious meal.
author: Andrew M.

description: I really like this place for dim sum. The ambience leaves something to be desired, but the food is spot on!
author: Taylor J.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE! 

I stumbled in after passing by and noticing that the restaurant had changed (tied to a hotel). I snuck in and ordered off the menu. The owner was there and he was super nice and friendly. Told me he owned other restaurants in SF. Since there is no local dim sum spot, I was praying the food would be a hit. 

Boy, it was! Everything is made to order (my order took a bit long- suggest you call in). It came out piping hot, fresh and so yummy. I highly recommend! I hope they stay because I will miss getting my dim sum fix.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
If you want great Asian food this is it. Perfect for sharing.
Must haves:
Hot and sour soup
Salt and pepper wings 
Beef chow fun
Peking duck

The off the menu item of orange chicken tastes like funnel cakes so hard pass on that.
author: Sarah P.

description: Food was great, service was excellent . We stayed at the hotel above it, so it was ver convenient
author: Fernando A.

description: Great location, since we were staying in the hotel. Food was tasty. The Kendall Jackson was priced reasonably. The only negative was that the wait staff barely spoke English. I would eat at this restaurant again if I visit that area.
author: Mark R.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because I sat back and was fed dim sum like royalty.

   ---   ---   ---

I never get tired of dim sum, but it's especially wonderful when you have people at the table that handle all of the ordering for the group. My contribution was, "make sure you get the one with the shrimp in the thing!" Outside of that, I sat, and I ate.

Every single bite was an easy 5-stars. Because I pretty much never even saw a menu, and I'm far from a connoisseur, I honestly have no idea what any of these lovely items were called. So just know this, reader of this review: order a lot of things. They are all wonderful.

One interesting fact that I learned about dim sum is that it's traditionally a breakfast item, and many dim sum restaurants in SF close before dinner. I definitely was not aware of that, and I think there's an untapped market here! Dim Sum makes for a phenomenal dinner, so stay open later SF dim sum restaurants!
author: Brett N.

description:
"Ouch!!!!"
"Just burned my mouuuuffffff!"
"Ah! That's hot...that's hot!"
"Uhf dawt iz zoe hawtt!" - mouth full of burning hot dumplings!

These lines and variations of them were spit out all night long from my tablemates (and myself) but they were always followed up with - "BUT IT'S SO GOOD!!!!"

I arrived with a group of 8. This place is no frills - but real deal. 

It took us a while to find a place that offered up dim sum for dinner - and after a fairly long search we came across the Dim Sum Club. Apparently dim sum is traditionally served for breakfast....but let's face it...any breakfast is delicious for dinner. Especially so, when it comes to dim sum. We shared a ton (and I mean a TON) of items...but here's what I remember:

Deep fried pork dumplings
Sui Mai
Har Gow (might of been my favorite!)
Xiao Long Bao
Pork buns

And I'd say a few others - really nothing we got was bad. We left super stuffed...rolling out of this place. GET IT ALL! Share with the table!

Dim sum all day! DIM SUM ALL DAY!
I wish I had gone back for one more fix....I was super jealous when I saw co-workers grabbing some to go the next morning for breakfast/for their flight.
author: Blue A.

description:
First ever Dim Sum experience and it did NOT disappoint! My group decided on Dim Sum because I hadn't ever had it. It was great to go with people that knew what they were doing! We allowed the two most tenured Dim Sumers to order for the table.

Although I didn't really know all of the names of the different dishes I can tell you that they were ALL AWESOME! Each came out with 4 or 5 pieces. What I loved the most about this was as soon as the Dim Sum was cooked, it came right to the table.  Super fresh!

Dim Sum Club did not disappoint this first timer! Definitely stop by if in San Fran!
author: Kellie M.

description:
This place must have gotten worse since earlier reviews.

1) Yelp now warns you this place is in the bottom 5% of all SF health ratings

2) There is no longer a $10 sampler

3) prices are now about $6.50-$6.95 per item, so pretty expensive for dim sum

4) we ordered 9 things. 1 was tasty, 2 were okay, and the other 6 were pretty bad. The Shanghai dumplings has no soup on them and seemed pretty shriveled/ dehydrated. The pot stickers were pretty tasteless

Not the worst, but definitely doesn't deserve 4 stars on Yelp
author: Lilly D.

description:
I was a customer at their sister restaurant on Irving and 22nd Ave.  I saw the business card and recognized that they were in my neighborhood so I opted to give them a try, especially since there are limited options for dim sum in my neck of the woods. Glad I did.

in all the years that I have frequented dim sum restaurants, this is the only one that ALWAYS steams the Chinese broccoli to perfection.   same goes for the sticky rice, dumplings and taro. 

I have been going to the Dim Sum Club for about 2 years. no reason to ha to Chinatown, Richmond or Sunset for dim sum. this place rocks.
author: Allan B.

description:
Brunch review. 

Dim sum - 3/5
Standouts - 4/5 - beef puffs, sticky rice
Desserts - 4/5 - Mango pudding is huge and awesome. Custard tarts are good as well.

Overall, quality dim sum, also open for dinner. "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Solid dim sum in a city with a lot of it. Service is quick and food is always hot. Highlights are Shanghai dumplings; good examples are hard to find! Shui mai, har gao and steamed noodle roll are all excellent. I'd avoid chow mein and Chinese food, however. They don't compare with dumpy quality.
author: Andrew J.

description: Worse dim sum I ever had in my life... Similar quality and worse than Chinatown. I have to say prices are not equivalent to the quality. Too much oil on the steam items...not impressed at all.
author: M W.

description: You're better off heading a bit further to eat in the Richmond. Or, if you're on the opposite side of the city, check out Shanghai Dumpling King. While the food is solid, this place is very overpriced, relative to equally good Chinese joints.
author: Paulina F.

description: Really great Chinese food. Was very pleased with everything we had, particularly the Shanghai Dumplings and the green beans with chicken. Soups are meant for sharing - they are huge. Portions are also very generous, also great for sharing.
author: Nikki K.

description: Love this place!  The food is tasty and the price is reasonable.
author: Mason W.

description: A really great Dim Sum place with everything freshly prepared. It's not in Chinatown, but that may be a good thing as the food appears to cater to locals more than tourists. The salt and pepper squid was perfect, with the steamed pork buns being the one thing where I thought the filling was a little lacking.  No fruit flies, as I see in a few reports.
