The closest good Chinese to the Fisherman's Wharf area!
author: Brian R.

description:
Delicious, non-chinese speaker friendly Dim Sum establishment.
Don't get me wrong, the place in Chinatown are amazing and authentic, but sometimes I'm not in the mood to practice my Chinese.

Enter... Dim Sum Club. 

Attached to a hotel, the Dim Sum Club offers delicious dishes at a slightly elevated price, compared to their Chinatown counterparts.

However, everything is delicious, juicy, and satisfying.

Get:
- sticky rice in lotus leaf
- shu mai
- turnip (daikon) cake
- congee

Skip:
- shrimp roll (the rice paper was too thick and chewy)
- shrimp dumplings (too expensive at $6)

5 stars for food... minus 1 star for the price. Also tea shouldn't be a dollar a person!!
author: Michelle L.

description: The food is great.  The staff is friendly.   Great dim sum.  Oh, I think I'll have to run over there soon!
author: Karen S.

description:
The Dim Sum Club has pretty solid Chinese food... Not extraordinary but definitely not bad. 

They do have a pretty extensive menu. 

We tried broccoli beef (nothing special but not bad), general tso chicken (slightly better than average), and mixed veggies (didn't care for the sauce they came in). 

Service was quick, and it's a very convenient option if you're staying at the Da Vinci Villa hotel that they restaurant is connected to.
author: Angela Z.

description:
Idk. Maybe I'm just not a dim sum person? I don't have much experience in this area of food honestly, but it looked good and it tasted decent. 
We just got a bunch of appetizers. Shrimp dumplings, pork and shrimp sui mai, steamed pork buns, and shanghai dumplings. Our favorite was the shanghai dumplings and the sui mai. They had the most flavor. The shrimp dumplings were a bit dull and the steamed pork buns, well... no. It was my first time trying them and they were not what I expected them to be like. But at least I tried them! They tasted kind of like a cinnamon roll which threw us off. It all looked good so I think if you like dim sum more then you would like this place. However, I've seen A LOT more inexpensive places in the city. 
The service was good, although we never got the tea we asked for. That's fine though because we weren't charged and honestly we forgot about it by the end.
author: Samantha O.

description:
Good luck not eating a fruit fly during your meal. We were attacked by flies the whole time, and it got so bad my girlfriend had to go outside because they wouldn't leave her or her food alone. The man sitting at the table next to us confronted a waitress about it and said the flies were like this 3 weeks ago too and that he wouldn't be returning. I have the say the same for us, this wasn't a place I would ever dine again or take anyone.
The food alone wasn't great, and I would have given 3 stars without flies. The xiao long bao had hard tops and leathery skin with smoothie like insides. The BBQ pork buns have lots of sauce on the inside. The porridge was not salted at all, but my girlfriend preferred that actually. 
I'd say you could try getting stuff to go, but with all the flies, I'm not sure of the cleanliness of their kitchen.
author: Adamme K.

description: We had the pork dim sum, hot and sour soup and broccoli and chicken.   All were fresh and great flavors.  Great choice while traveling because of the fresh veggies and great flavors.
author: Scott C.

description: This place is GREAT! My husband is chinese and we have been eating dim sum for several years now. We use to venture out to Clement St but now we come here! The food is very fresh!
author: Karen F.

description: Best dim sum for this area!  Freshly made! Large portions for lunch specials. Hardly ever crowded. Attentive staff. Great price.  FINALLY good dim sum in the Marina!
author: Vivian E.

description: got a late lunch at the dim sum club whilst staying in San fran.  The food was excellent. We got loads of different dim sum dishes. Highly recommend the sui Mai really big and juicy.  service was a little abrupt but acceptable.  Food came out really fast as soon as it was prepared meaning it was all really piping hot and fresh.
author: Tobias S.

description: Very slow service. Food was good but plates came out in odd individual, ten minute intervals for our table of four. One order was wrong & they treated us as a nuisance for asking that it be corrected
author: Jon W.

description:
Love love love this place. I've come here two separate time with different sized crowds and they've been able to seat us promptly all around lunch hour. You order via a menu sheet and they'll bring the items to you which seems to contribute to their speedy service! 

I personally love steamed dim sum items vs fried items so I usually order the pork/shrimp shumai, shrimp dumplings, bbq pork buns, rice noodles, wonton soup, etc. All of which are fresh and tasty without being too salty. Also, the price is pretty fair, particularly compared to some options in the FiDi.

All in all, this is a really solid dim sum place and I am definitely returning!
author: Alex P.

description:
This place is great for a quick lunch. They have standard cantonese dishes such as Chow Fun, dim sum and other chinese dishes. The service isnt that good, but it works. The staff aren't that fluent in english so I wouldn't ask for recommendations. A good tip is to use google and other yelp reviews to know what to and not choose. I really liked their Shrimp Ha Kow dumpling. It tasted home-made but I did not have any time to confirm this with the waitress.

All in all, a great place for lunch that is not costy. I ate lunch here twice during my stay in SF.
author: Kai C.

description: The experience was a 5.  The food was probably a 5.  I think the service is the only reason I am giving this a 4.  Service was about a 3. They would not split our check 4 ways and allow us to pay.  They took too long for water fillups as well.  But despite that and if you are not splitting checks and if you do not drink like a camel you should really go here.  The food was fantastic.  We all got apps and split them up.  Everyone's favorite was my salt and pepper calamari.  This is a must.  I then got the $10 Dim Sum deal.  What a crazy amount of food for $10 and I did not like one of my 5 items but had already had plenty.  I was not a fan of the steamed pork bun.  But the shrimp dumpling and the shrimp and pork siu mai were perfect.  You can not get this kind of stuff from where I am from so I tried it several times over the weekend.  This was also the only place I had the Peking Duck while there and was impressed with their tableside preparation.  The steamed buns and scallions and sauce were fantastic together and the duck by itself was also extraordinary.  The eggroll was good as well.  If they were a little better with groups of 5 wanting to split a check I may consider a 5.  But definitely worth the trip!
author: Ryan H.

description:
Finally a club where I can be my true self at.....

I'm the type of girl who craves dumplings for breakfast, lunch, and dinner so whenever I go to San Francisco I head out to Good Mong Kok bakery in the wee hours of the morning to get myself a bag o' dim sum to munch on throughout the day. With Dim Sum Club, I no longer have to subject myself to hours old dim sum, warmed up by the radiator of my hotel room.

There were two parts of my meal. Regular menu and the special pink menu that they only reserve for the real Asians in the know (apparently Xerxes and I don't count).

A few standout dishes (which is hard to remember since our table was literally plates on plates on plates):
- Har Gow: Easily, one of my favorite dumplings we ordered a basket for each person at the table...plus more. We were hungry using up all of our brain power that day ok!?!? These shrimps must have come from radiated waters because they were cartoon size! Not that I was complaining. The dumpling wrapper was delicate and the perfect carby foil to those big ass skrimps.
- Shrimp Crepes: Pretty much har gow in crepe form but as I said we used a lot of brain power that day. 
- BBQ Pork Buns - An even meat to bun to ratio and stuffed full of tasty, tasty morsels of red tinged meat. The breading was soft and fresh.
- Turnip Cakes: On point 
- Singapore Street Noodles: Dumplings are not exactly the most filling thing in the world so this was a good way to coat our tummies with something before we got into the real deal pink menumeal.

Which...I cannot even talk correctly about since our table leader ordered everything in Cantonese. Let's just call it even and say it was delicious.

My favorite menu item was an egg omelette with more of those big ass shrimps tossed in. The eggs had the texture of Charmin Ultra Soft + Fluffy White Clouds + Unicorn Magic all mixed together. It was a simple, homey dish that had me googling recipes as soon as I got on the plane.

If I were a local, I'd be clubbin' here every weekend.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Low key, inexpensive, and tasty dim sum in Pac Heights. The servers were very friendly and helpful and we enjoyed everything we ordered. The highlights were the fantastic hot and sour wonton soup (large portion so share with a big group!), turnip cakes, the fried pork and chives dumplings and the pork buns, which were huge. Off the regular menu we tried the fried rice and chicken Kung pao. Both were fine but I highly recommend coming here just for the awesome dim sum.
author: Sol C.

description:
This restaurant is on the ground floor of a hotel on Van Ness, and felt pretty different from typical grungy SF dim sum places in the Richmond. It was fairly quiet inside, service was really friendly, and it was clean....even the bathroom was pretty clean. 

How was the food? Well it was gorgeous. Everything was so beautiful I almost didnt want to eat it ( got over that quickly enough.)  Ingredients were pretty good quality 
( e.g. whole shrimp in the har gow) and there were some interesting/unusual offerings. It was nice to try something new, and I liked everything except the salt and pepper calamari which was deep fried in some sort of thick sweet batter. Blech. Well, and the bean curd roll was only ok ( not blech, just kinda meh.)

Be warned that tea is not complimentary, but that means it's really good. We had a rich, smoky black tea for a dollar...worth every penny (wow Im cheap...nobody else even cares that the tea isn't free, huh?)

I'll be back.
author: El B.

description: Came here for dim sum brunch. Loved the BBQ pork steamed buns, shanghai dumplings and stuffed eggplants, the rest of the order was so-so (fried pork puffs, pork noodle rolls and chives dumplings). I wasn't really a fan of the diner vibe I got from this place.
author: Thewanderingmutt B.

description: Service was very friendly and attentive. We made a mistake on the bill and they were kind enough to return the excess money
author: Monchito R.

description: The place is just ok. This is not an authentic dim sum place. I don't know why they call it dim sum club, but it at least it satisfied my hunger.
author: Mitos E.

description:
The dim sum here is surprisingly great!

Located in Russian Hill inside a hotel, it couldn't be in a less appropriate location. When you step inside, it's missing that frenzied, warm, well-lit environment you'd expect. The interior feels more like a diner. It even has bar seating.

Prices are high compared to favorites like Lai Hong Lounge and Hong Kong Lounge; e.g., shrimp dumplings are $6.50, shrimp noodle roll is $6.75. Given the environment and prices, I had low hopes for this place... until our food came!

Their beef w/ cilantro noodle roll is the best I've had in the city! Really great flavor, not too oily, good quality meat. The baked BBQ pork buns were freshly baked and just crumbled when biting into it - really good. Overall, the dim sum felt well-executed and healthier with quality ingredients.

Also, there was no line!

Overall, if you just want quality dim sum and are willing to pay for it, you should come here!
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
At first, I was a little hesitant walking into the Dim Sum Club. Growing up, I was used to going to dim sum in large ballrooms with the ladies pushing the carts. Dim Sum Club is more of a traditional sit-down restaurant feel. There are plenty of booths and some tables. The service is fast and efficient but there are no ladies pushing carts. You select your items from the menu in English. Having been to Dim Sum many times before, I knew exactly what I wanted and was surprised to see so many items to choose from. 

My table of 5 ordered:
-BBQ pork buns
-banana leaf with sticky rice
-thick noodles with fish (one of my favorites)
-steamed shrimp dumpling
-soup pork dumplings
-shrimp and vegetable dumplings
-egg tart
-steamed egg custard bun

I was thoroughly impressed. The quality of the food was very good and the price was very resonable. I think we spent $17 each including tip. I will definitely come back!
author: Norah C.

description:
Smaller than expected and order from a menu as opposed to from carts, but the food was really fantastic...better than expected. Some friends thought it was cheap, but I thought it was a little more than other places. 

There were 11 of us in our group, and we were treated well. The total came out to about $20 a person. The owner came over a few times to check on us and I think he sent a free dish (or maybe we were charged for it, I didn't inspect the bill).

I'd certainly go back and would highly recommend this place. 

Servers didn't speak English all that well, which is typical and in my opinion a sign of a great dim sum place, but one friend was allergic to shell fish and later found out one of the dumplings was made with shrimp, not fish. (She's OK)
author: Penguin S.

description:
The $99 dinner for 4 is SO much food and a great deal! For $99 you get:

- the biggest bowl ever of delicious shrimp tofu soup
- fried rice or noodles
- Peking duck with buns
- your choice of any 4 additional entrees!

For our additional entrees, we had a dim sum platter, prawns and broccoli, a spicy tofu dish, and a fish fillet dish (also with a bit of spice). Everything was delicious!

Our waitress was very attentive and made sure our water glasses were always full. A nice older gentleman who I would guess is the owner also came by to check on us a few times and gave us each a delicious mango and coconut milk dessert to go with our fortune cookies (which had strange fortunes!).

The meal could have easily fed at least 6 people and we took tons of leftovers home. I'd love to go back sometime when I feel like feasting!

Note: the space is not fancy and there were not a lot of other guests. I think Dim Sum Club is just a well-kept secret for now!
author: Meghan P.

description: I was very satisfied by our choice of dim sums...the Shanghai dumplings actually had soup broth in it and was placed in aluminum plates that helped not to break. It was really good and so were the sui mai dumplings.
author: Divya R.

description:
While the food is still fresh and piping hot, they certainly have increased their prices. Previously many of the offerings that were $3-4 are now $6-6.50. We ordered about the same as last time again but our total came to $60ish for 2 (previously was roughly $40ish for 2). 

Still, if the quality stays this consistent I'll continue to frequent! Service is also good for a Chinese restaurant. Space is open and has a pretty decent layout but does have that cafeteria vibe, so this won't make the most romantic ambiance for dinner, but it's perfect for a lunch spot. Great for couples, friends, families and larger groups.
author: Veronica S.

description: The shrimp in the fried rice was rotten and the chefs had no idea what to tell us and there are bugs crawling around the place. If you want to eat rotten, undercooked fish whilst staring at cockroaches and getting food poisoning, this is the perfect place to go!
author: Ariana T.

description:
There is dim sum near Cow Hollow, in Russian Hill.

Yes, you read that correctly.

If you want your Chinese food or dim sum fix and are too lazy to venture out, this is acceptable.

If you want to get the most authentic food (with the most authentic prices), head elsewhere (Chinatown, the Richmond, Sunset).

The food tasted like what it's supposed to - really no complaints, but nothing spectacular either.  The restaurant is nice and clean, and service is nice and polite (which is probably a good indicator that it's not as authentic as it can be, hah!).  Menu items for dinner included things geared towards the Americanized tastebuds: General Tso's chicken, walnut prawns (personally this is my favorite of the whitewashed menu), broccoli beef, etc. but you can find stuff like ma po tofu or XLB here.

There didn't seem to be any porridge on the dinner menu, but apparently it's online for their lunch menu, and it's a really nice, piping hot meal for cold SF days.  I'll have to go back and try during lunch/dim sum times to get a full picture of their dim sum items, since we only tried the appetizer platter (2 har gow, 2 siu mai, an egg roll - bleh, 1 pork bun, and 2 sesame mochi balls with red bean).

Decent.  Not the best obviously, but for a lazy night in the area, it's just fine.
author: Tori S.

description:
"The chair is dirty!"  Well you don't have to eat the chair so ... I liked DSC.  Off the beaten Chinatown path and everything seemed to be cooked to order.  I like that.  The "Crispy Roast Duck" got good comments from everyone at our table and the leftovers tasted good later in the day.  The decor leaves a bit to be desired but it's a cool walk in place, they know what they are doing and if you want, you can watch them make your food if you grab a counter seat.  Skip the char siu bows (pork buns), those were pretty weak for the price point.  Made me miss Cafe Bakery on Noriega Street.  But minor disappointment.  

The calamari had a nice light batter and was fried with skill.  They are making an effort here.

For what it is, it is good.  Nothing fancy but it's not priced fancy so I will be returning since it's also walking distance from my flat on Russian Hill.
author: Terry A.

description: Super convenient and no line, a nice alternative to the better known dim sum options in the Richmond. Fast service and food is served hot, definitely would come back. Dim sum food quality is not stand out, but definitely good enough for me on a Sunday when I am not looking to wait an hour in line.
author: Shirley L.

description: I work in the heart of Chinatown so I have access to great Chinese food and dim sum at great prices every day.  Dim Sum Club has a little higher prices but the quality of the food is very good.  It feels like a $$$ food with $$1/2 atmosphere and $$1/2 price.  Today we were there very early so got $$$$ service.
author: Jayn J.

description:
So happy to have found this gem in Russian Hill. Seems a little strange to have a great dimsum restaurant in this neighborhood but we like this place a lot more than many of the dimsum restos in Chinatown.

It's always busy and buzzy, but we never have to wait too long when we come at lunch time on Saturdays or Sundays. Great selection of dimsum favorites (shrimp dumplings, shu mai, baked/steamed pork buns, Shanghai soup dumplings), as well as regular Chinese restaurant fare (fried rice, stir fried veggie, Peking duck, etc).
author: Anna B.

description: I've passed this place almost everyday for the past couple years, and finally gave it a try today. The inside decor is simple, and nothing to cheer about, however the dim sum is spot on. They serve almost all of the same things during dinner that you would find at a lunch, which is atypical for dim sum. The food was all piping hot, and served very fresh. You could tell it was all pan fried, steamed, or wok'd up right before coming to the table. Don't be scared that it's in the bottom of a hotel, give it a try the next time you're in the marina.
author: Josh F.

description:
Best bang for the dim sum buck.  Pleasantly surprised by service & spacious ambience.  Ideally, come after 1pm for a non-line on Sunday.

Cons: Street parking may be hard to find; allot time for this.
author: Ben H.

description:
What a great place to spend Mother's Day.  I'm glad we arrived early because as soon as we were seated, this place packed up!  
Service is your typical Dim Sum but the Manager occasionally checked in on us.  The food was delicious.  Way better than most Dim Sums we've been to.  Large selection as well as non Dim Sum food.  It's served straight from the kitchen, not from carts being pushed around, which means your food is fresh.
author: Arlene M.

description:
We really enjoyed the dim sum and wish we lived nearby.....
Our waitress was very friendly and courteous. The food tasted excellent 
We had shrimp and sticky rice and it was gone !
author: Andy S.

description:
Love this place! Clean and fresh! I highly recommend the Dim Sum and Won Ton Soup.
Friendly service and food is fabulous. I work a block away and happy to have them close by.
author: Dawn C.

description: I am a bit skeptical when it comes to high prices for food. I want to save money on food. But at the time we were looking for something with not a big line and of course we were on our last day of our trip and it was a weekend. So, of course most dim sum places are going to be busy on the weekend. Thankfully, we got parking and this place was not too busy. The dim sum dishes were filling and appetizing. The signature dish that pulled it off was the chow mein (HK Style) which means it's crispy noodles that compliments the ingredients. You can guess why the prices are high, because it's connected to a small hotel. That's the main reason why. The staff is quite welcoming. Although some of the dishes had been sold out because of the time we were there,, we did get a complimentary dessert which was mango pudding. I, wouldn't mind coming here to eat dim sum again. The quality was A+. Sometimes, you have to aim for quality than quantity. I left Dim Sum Club not full, but satisfied. That is when you know the meal is great. As to restrooms, they are in the hotel which you have access if you eat at the restaurant. The kitchen is visible to the naked eye and the staff is quite accomodating. I would definitely recommend coming back here again! Favorite dim sum dishes were the sui mai, fried radish pancake, and HK style chow mein.
author: Arthur W.

description:
Food is great and fresh out of the steamer/ kitchen
Great selection of food at a reasonable price 

1 star off for the awkward setup - restaurant is also used as hotel breakfast so it has the buffet table and booth unlike traditional dimsum restaurant
author: B N.

description: After hearing my friends rave about it, I decide to try dim sum for the first time. Overall the experience was okay. I ordered the house pan noodle which was decent but my complaint is that the dim sim platter fell short of expectations. This food was extremely oily as well, do not order the egg rolls!
author: Rachel T.

description: Had a variety of items here with my family, including several dim sum items, fried rice, and chicken tofu. One of my favorites was the pork and shrimp siu mai, which had good flavor, texture. In general, we were happy with the taste. The variety of dim sum available could have been improved as well as their menu itself; there weren't pictures of the items, and maybe it's just me, but I never remember the names of the dim sum, but know it by look. I sure do miss having more push cart dim sum places!
author: Will H.

description:
SO. MANY. DUMPLINGS.

Food: 5/5
Service: 2/5
Atmosphere: LOLZ.... Think cafeteria

Aiiight, so my friend and I hit this place up on a Friday after one of the longest weeks on record, totally ready to grub out and relax. Our verdict: This place totally slayed the food game, but the service game was hella off. 

It's commonly known (Thanks, Yelp) that the service here is kinda just touch-and-go, and it's very true. Does that mean you shouldn't eat here? No. You probably should because the food is amazing. I'd definitely come again. Why? Because when it comes to dim sum, I care about food more than service. Why? Because dumplings.

Things you should absolutely order:
- Salt and Pepper Calamari (amazingly fresh and delicious)
- Shanghai soup dumplings (FLAVORful)
- Walnut Shrimp (so sweet and delicious)
- Pork buns (superb flavor)

Things to consider: 
- Shrimp dumplings (The same as everywhere else)
- Pork potstickers (strange sauce, but good)

Things NOT to waste your $ on: 
- Shrimp and Pork Fried Rice (Flavorless meh)


SUMMER TOURISTS AND WHALES BE WARNED: If you're thirsty, ask for water sooner rather than later. It's a scarce resource up in here.
author: Andrea D.

description:
Dim Sum Club replaces Cafe Como(an ill-fated mexican eatery) with dim sum and cantonese cuisine at lunch. 

arriving prenoon, i signaled to persons standing at cashiers counter   i wanted a table for 2. she stared at me strangely.  turns out she's waiting for a table also.

no greeter on duty. just 2 frantic associates running around dispensing food checked off on a list.

eats:
-pan-fried potstickers (4/3.75)
undercooked, insides just warm, sent it back.
-bbq pork bun (3/3.25)
doughy bun texture, fillings tasteless but loaded with msg
-beef chow fun (8)
waiter forgot to order, tasteless when it came out, beef very tender
-shrimp in noodle crepe(5.25)
crunchy shrimp, almost tasty, crepe skin fell apart. 
small portion.
-spareribs(3.25)
fatty ribs pieces makes this tastier than it is.
little meat taste, portion ok
-tea 1@person, tea nice,

take outs:
-dining area just 8 booths, 7 tables ,seats about 50.
booths too cramped, couldn't fit my mansize body in.
-no hostess, buspersons on duty, 2 associates were energized bunnies, unable to provide adequate services.
-Dim Sum Club outside signage difficult to see, partially obscured by trees.
rating: service-1 (sparse), food (2.5) msg, pricey, small portion, tasteless
-worst food experience in a while with SO, she keep reminding me, so 2 stars
side note: food comparable with Jack's: misguided.
-food came out quickly. service memorable as to effort.
fwiw: with a few minor twerks in the food and service, 4 stars easily attainable.
author: Victor G.

description: Great option for decent dim sum without a crazy line. Soup dumplings threw me off at first because they come in little tins, but tasted great! Everything else I ordered tasted good, too!
author: Betty H.

description:
My cousin wanted to have Sunday lunch near her house at this dim sum place. I was skeptical of this place, especially when my cousin told me it was a little dinky place attached to a hotel near her apartment. After the trek up the hill onto Van Ness, I was surprised. It was not as dinky as she described it was, or maybe my definition of dinky is skewed.

We were promptly greeted by a waiter that recognized my cousin. Apparently when we went they just opened at most a few months ago and it used to be a hotel restaurant. Whatever that means. It was a bit busy, we had to wait a few minutes for a table. We were offered a booth but figured since we wanted to taste... I don't know maybe the entire menu we opted to wait for a bigger table.

After a few minutes a table left and we were prompted to sit and peruse the menu. We ended up ordering a lot of food, we had an extended table and that filled up too. I have noticed they don't utilize the space of the restaurant well enough, it seems they could do better but that's just me. They have an open kitchen in the front with another smaller one in the back.

As we placed the order we started talking about what is going on in our lives and after a while we all thought, hmm it's taking a bit of time. Wrong statement to say because after that our half a roasted duck came, our shrimp dumpling came, then the chicken feet, then the Shanghai dumplings, then the Shu Mai and on and on and on quickly too one right after another, until all our dishes came out and it all smelled and looked amazing. We spent about 80 bucks for 4 people and we were stuffed. 

The color on the roasted duck was really nice and it wasn't too fat. The steamed rice rolls tasted fresh, just made and not sandy at all. They also include a side of vegetables with the steamed rice rolls. The rest of the dim sum tasted so good, I can't go into detail on why it tasted good because frankly I can't remember everything we ordered.

Another thing that was delicious was the salt and pepper fried chicken wings. The light batter along with the almost perfect frying time for the chicken wings accompanied with the salt and pepper. MMM makes me want to go back for more. I think the only things that we could've skipped was the dumplings (some soup dumplings) and the pan fried green chives dumplings. The soup one you could get better at San Tung in Sunset district and the pan fried green chives dumpling, the skin was too gooey. Now gooey isn't a bad thing, but too gooey gets stuck in your teeth and is a bit of an annoyance to eat.

The waiters and waitress are all so pleasant. I was told they have dim sum in the evenings also. I must go back. In one hand I wish them all the business they can possibly have, but if that happens, then I can never get a table when I want to.

Oh well, I hope this place stays fantastic. Trust that I'll be back.

Cheers!
author: Harry P.

description: I was directed here after my friend told me that this place is not nearly as busy as the other famous dim sum places but still really good.  I got there at 11am and there wasn't a wait.  All of the famous dumpling items were delicious.  The soup was also very good but the vegetables were just okay.
author: Ted Y.

description: For dim sum outside of the Richmond District, this place was pretty good. There was no line and we were seated quickly. The service was attentive for a Chinese restaurant, and the food came out rather quickly. Overall the food was okay, it wasn't super memorable, but not terrible either. If I didn't want to make the trek to the typical dim sum neighborhoods in SF, this place would pass for satisfying a dim sum craving.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Sweet, a good dim sum place in SF that doesn't have monstrous wait times! (assuming you arrive by 1130 or closer to 1pm) We ordered too much food here and walked out with a little bit of leftovers; $16pp for 4, but could be a few bucks less if we ordered in moderation. They had some slightly different variations on dishes than I've seen in other dim sum places, e.g.: salted pork bone porridge, spare rib noodle rolls - thought those were gonna have the paiguat rolled up inside, but it was served on top of the steamed rolled noodles), a lotus paste sesame ball (really yummy). Liked it all, except don't bother with the durian puffs, which are quite pungent, haha. Oh yes, the XLB are my new SF favorite I think!
author: Linus W.

description:
I usually drive to Daly City for dimsum but was excited to hear of Dim Sum Club opening up in my neighborhood and decided to give it a try. 

Prices here are definitely a little bit higher compared to your average dimsum restaurant, but the quality is actually pretty good. They have a good sized menu with your typical dimsum dishes: spareribs, chicken feet, siu mai, shrimp dumplings, shanghai dumplings, egg tarts, buns, etc... + additional rice and noodle plates. 

Service was good and the food came out pretty quick. Since this is a rather new establishment, you can tell that the employees are still somewhat adapting. Nonetheless, if I dont feel like making the drive to Daly City in the future, I will definitely be back.
author: M W.

description: Loved the Dim Sum.  I would eat here again next time I'm in SF.  The lightly breaded and then fried spare ribs were tasty, as were the steamed pork buns.
author: Johnnie O.

description:
I wanted to like this place coz I like dim sum made to order, it's a lot more fresh that way. But sorry, apart from this aspect this place falls short in everything else. 

We went on a weekend and there were plenty of vacant tables, which isn't a good sign. But that's not the first thing that you notice - the smell hits you right when you walk in. It's soooooo oily and stuffy in there! 

There aren't a lot to choose from, but we managed to order some of the usual items. The food came pretty quickly, which is kind of expected because there weren't too many tables and the staff seemed to be idle most of the time. 

I'll just comment on the things NOT to order (in case you REALLY want to try this place still):

Rice roll (Cheung fun) with fried dough - the original name is called 'ja leung' in Cantonese. It looked good but when I took a bite, I realized the dough was toooooo deep-fried there's no 'dough' in it, it's just a crispy piece. This is NOT what ja leung should be like, but granted, most if not all Bay Area dim sum places don't get this right. I'm just disappointed because it looked really promising. 

Steamed bun with egg yolk - these looked horrible when they landed on our table. They looked as if there was an explosion and the egg yolk bursted. They just looked so wrong! The taste was okay though but I still find them slightly over-steamed because the egg yolk wasn't in liquid form. 

We also ordered har gow, siu mai, sesame balls and some vegetable dumplings. They were all okay but nothing to write home about. 

Again, if this place charges what most other chinese restaurants in the area charge, then it's not terrible, just nothing I would recommend. But the prices are way higher than other places (most dim sum items being at least $1.5-2 higher than other places in the area), so you naturally expect more, given there's also no decor to speak of (not to mention the stuffiness). I would say, avoid this place, there are many much better options in the city.
author: Essie L.

description: 3.5 prices are up, but still decent hot, greasy, standard offerings.  had shrimp dumpling, nice and plump, with combination panfried crispy noodles (a little less sauce and could have had more crispy noodles) and fish tofu claypot (fish very limp)
author: Rob C.

description:
The Dim Sum Club is hard to quantify (as in Yelp stars).  On one hand, the food is pretty good, service acceptable, room is OK and it serves dim sum for dinner.  On the other, it's kind of expensive and the room is actually the hotel's breakfast buffet room.  

3 of us went there the celebrate a friend's birthday for dinner.  Thought it would a little different than your standard Chinese restaurant.  On a Tuesday around 6:30pm, the place was pretty empty and we had our pick of tables or booths.  Service came quickly and brought us tea and water.  We ordered some sui mai and cha sui bau to start.  Both were very good.  Turns out the dim sum is made to order.

Later we ordered their ma po tofu and chicken with double mushrooms and some rice.  Both dishes were also very good, although the ma po tofu was a little spicy for us.

The bad: prices are high.  Not Yang SIng high, but Dim Sum Club is not that nice.  Paper napkins, hotel buffet room, not really high end.  More like good Chinese restaurant quality at twice the price.

We figured they were catering more the tourist crowd or the local Union St crowd.  For my money I'd rather go to Chinatown or Richmond.  Unless it's dim sum for dinner, in which case Dim Sum Club is a good option.
author: Steve G.

description:
In the (dim sum) club, VIP, no guest list!!! 

Don't even need to be on the guest list to get in this club.  In all seriousness though, this is probably my favorite dim sum place in the city.  There's never a really long wait and this place much, much cleaner than anything you'll find in Chinatown.  

I'd recommend the typical dim sum plates like shumai, shrimp dumplings, shrimp noodle roll, etc.  But I think their baked pork buns and wonton soup are some of the best I've had.  Enjoy!
author: Candace C.

description:
UPDATE: Just went again (11/2) and the prices have nearly all gone up. Lowest priced dim sum is $4 now :( I would drop the rating down to 3 1/2 stars now. 
------------

From our visit in October:

Overall excellent choice outside of Chinatown. Not the best, but very good.

Shanghai Soup Dumplings ($5.50) - Good, but should be steamed over a cabbage leaf as a couple of dumplings ripped :(

Curry Samosa ($2.99) - really good, never see this in dim sum

BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll ($4.25) - thin rice wrap good meat filling

Pork and Perserved Egg Porridge  ($5.50) comes with side of fried donut/condiments. Not watery - very good

Beef and egg (your choice of style) over rice ($6.50) was delicious and could've have been a lunch on it's own!

Salt and Pepper Calamari ($5.50) was good, but be warned, like most other chinese places, they do use MSG. Tip - Salt and Pepper includes MSG.

Service was friendly and attentive.

Bathroom was clean...now try and find it...door #1, #2, #3?!? You'll see :P

Dm Sum Club is located in the Da Vinci Villa hotel and it shares the same space as the Da Vinci Villa Cafe, which opens from 7-10am. That explains the funky cafe/diner style set up of Dim Sum Club. The middle table and side tables setup for the morning continental breakfast stays in the restuarant 24/7, so it looks funny. Not DSC's fault.

Guangdong Barbecue Tea House on Irving is on the opposite side of thier business card, so I assume it's a sister restaurant.
author: Peter L.

description:
My husband and I have eaten here twice and we love it.  
Get the salt and pepper short ribs if you know what's good for you!
Soup dumplings are fantastic. Siu Mai is fantastic. They have a nice, but small selection of wine.  We haven't checked out the beer or sake but I'm sure it's sufficient.  
The older gentleman server seems to be running the joint, though I don't think he's the owner.  Very professional and knowledgable. 
I don't mind that it's not super traditional dim sum.  Everything is piping hot, fresh and made to order. 
Only thing I can say negative I always get a little heartburn after, but probably my fault from eating so much of their house made hot sauce with everything.
Dim Sum YUM!!!
author: Christiana G.

description: The food was OK but the service was terrible. 3/4 dishes came out within five minutes of each other. No one came to check in on me after that. I waited 20 mins for the last dish and it was obvious they'd forgotten about it. I told the waitress I'd like it taken off my bill. She then runs to the kitchen tells them to make it (it's an open air kitchen) and then comes back to tell me that it's coming. I don't like being cheated and I really don't like liars. Too bad it's the only dim sum place in the area.
author: Jackie L.

description:
Because my grandparents made a rule that I MUST have dim sum with them at least once a week, good dim sum is really important in my family.
This place is still fairly new and part of a hotel, so the decor is somewhat weird still, but that's the only negative thing about it.

Service is excellent! The waiters and waitresses all had a friendly smile on their faces. One of them even poured us more tea! SO NICE.

All of their dimsum is made fresh and HOT. 

-Beef w/ Cilantro Noodle Roll ($4.25): Very nice. The rice noodle crepe was thin and smooth. The beef was also very tasty! I did ask them to drench the plate with sweet soy sauce though haha. Excellent dish!

-Shanghai Dumpling ($5.50, 6 pieces): to my surprise, this was really good. I've ordered this at countless dimsum places and the outside was always thick and the inside was never juicy. This was pretty legit! Thin outer layer and the meat was very juicy and aromatic. They even give you spoons on the side so the soup won't spill out (:

-Salt and Pepper Chicken Wing ($4.50, 4 pieces): definitely not what I expected. It was pretty interesting; they made it into a "lollipop chicken style" by taking one of the two bones out and pushing all the meat to one end to make it look like a lollipop. It was pretty fun to eat, but they added too much batter to fry this so the crust was too thick. The flavor was great though. Came with a mayo dipping sauce.

-Deep Fried Pork Puff ($3.50): this was "whatevers" to me, because of my own personal preference. I like the outside to be thicker and more chewy. This was thin and crunchy. My grandparents loved this because they like crunchy stuff so I guess it's really up to you.

-Curry Samosas ($2.95): wow. This was surprisingly really good. The flavors really hit us and it was a great snack to have. The dipping sauce was pretty good and wasn't watered down. Definitely give this a try!

-Deep Fried Taro Dumpling ($3.25): man oh man I LOVE DF TARO DUMPLINGS. Dimsum Club made it happen! The outside layer was very loose and "fluffy". The taro on the inside was smooth and tasty with the meat and sauce. UUUGH SO GOOD.

-Shrimp Dumpling ($4.75): this was okay, nothing special. Just your average shrimp dumpling I guess. 

-Pork and Shrimp Siu Mai ($3.75): another okay dish. I do have to say that the fatty pork versus the lean pork ratio was pretty good, so the texture was good.

I would definitely come back to try more stuff! (:
author: Jackie T.

description: I went passed this place so many times without knowing it's there while running in the neighbourhood. My co-workers suggested to go for dim sum. We got there around noon on Sunday. We got a table right away though after us there was a line to get the table. There were lot of locals and not many tourists which we thought was a good sign. Food was delicious! We will definitely go back there. The only thing was that we could not communicate well with waiter when we asked questions but that was expected and minor issue. Highly recommend this place.
author: Tomoe S.

description: Everything I had was good and I'm glad this is an option in the neighborhood when I'm in the dim sum mood. The Shanghai dumplings was the best dish of our meal. I thought the pork buns, onion cakes and walnut shrimp were solid but I have had better. The vegetarian dumplings left me wanting more and was bland. Generally for the price it is hard to complain but it's not on the level of yank sing.
author: Derek S.

description: As a Guangzhou Zai（Cantonese），it really suits my taste. Especially 凤爪（Chicken feet), 肠粉（rice noodle rolls），粥（porridge）. If you want to eat local guangzhou food，you must eat here.
author: Jun X.

description:
Officially my favorite cantonese food in San Francisco! (coming from a Chinese person if that's worth anything) 
Don't be fooled by its generic name and label as a hotel restaurant. The price tag's higher than I'd like to pay for Chinese food, BUT it tastes so good and the food quality is great!

It's the only Chinese place that I crave almost weekly. Unfortunately it's far from Soma so I'll either drive to pick up (20 mins), or pay a ridiculous premium for a Postmates delivery ($20 to Soma, argh!)

House crispy noodles 
Roasted duck (YUM)
Stir fried big pea sprouts (healthy delicious offset to the other flavorful dishes)
Mushrooms with Tofu (not your average tofu, SO GOOD!)
author: Nattie X.

description: Delicious! Everything is made to order fresh so the dim sum is always hot off the oven or pan. The other dishes like house pan fried noodles are gratuitous in serving and worth the money! There is never a wait here and service is so fast and efficient. I think this Dim sum restaurant is the best in the city!
author: CHristine J.

description:
Not as cheap as Chinatown but seriously some of the freshest shu mai I've ever had. I fell in LOVE with their baked bbq pork buns oh my gosh...

Service here is very friendly and quick, plus it feels clean. It's located right by the Da Vinci hotel, so at first you might not notice it but it's definitely worth a visit.

Already excited for my next trip here!
author: Denise R.

description: Best. Dim Sum. Ever. This is a must!!! The atmosphere is friendly and open, and that is just beginning. We came only for Dim Sum, and they serve it all day long. The steamed pork buns were the best I've ever had. The Shanghai dumplings were perfectly done made an came when an incredible soy/vinegar sauce. The Shrimp and Pork Siu Mai were amazing. I have no idea how they get that much shrimp flavor into a dumpling!!!! The best...we had two orders of pork buns, one order of Shanghai dumplings, and one order of the Siu Mai with tea for two...and the grand total was $22. Amazing. A must for anyone wanting dim sum!
author: Ellen N.

description: I would definitely not go here for the ambiance, little ordinary and plain inside. The food was also just ok in my opinion. The dumplings were pretty good, but the fried rice was not my favorite and I was really disappointed in the BBQ pork bun (which is usually my favorite thing!). Service was pretty good and it was very affordable, so those were pluses.
author: Sarah P.

description:
The dim sum here is delicious! Some of the choices are unbelievably  stellar. Take for instance, the shrimp rice noodle roll otherwise known as ha cheurng fun. There is a rather generous size whole shrimp in each cut piece. The deep fried taro puff is on the smaller side. It's mostly taro but not greasy at all.  the Shanghai dumpling had an ample portion of filling but it didn't have enough broth. 

Contrary to the posted pictures, the dining room is very nice. there are some booths and some banquettes with hard chairs on the aisle side of the table. Service was friendly and efficient. 

There are no carts.  Mark  your choices on a menu.  Many of the dishes had 4 pieces. Perfect when there are four of you.  I didn't pay but I assume the prices were more reasonable than some of the other more popular dim sum places. 

Parking is difficult in this neighborhood. Muni was my ride. This is definitely a San Francisco go-to dim sum place  for me.
author: Debbie T.

description: Can only speak to the vege options but the dim sum is fresh and delicious. Not difficult to get a table on a Sunday brunch time and service is excellent. And a good deal!
author: Jerry R.

description:
More like a 3.5.

It'll do when you don't want to wait in lines, but still want a sit-down experience. A little pricier, but still not more than $25/pp even when we ordered more than we could finish in one sitting. 

They have the basics, but if you're looking for tripe or beef haslet, you won't find it here. 

Dim sum is served to order. I actually prefer that over the carts since everything's piping hot when it gets to the table.

The beef chow fun is good enough. Reheats well for taking to work the next day, in case you're like me and have to bring lunch to work!
author: Tinna H.

description:
Tried out a new Dim Sum place while visiting my sister in San Fran. This place is besides a hotel and away from Chinatown. We went the day after thanksgiving. Place opened at 11am. Staff was friendly and served food quickly. The menu does not have pictures like most dim places have but they explain what each item is.We ordered the basics and tried out some new dishes since my sister turned vegan. All the food was out of this world! 
We ordered pan fried turnip cakes, chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, har gow, shrimp & chives dumplings, shrimp and vegetarian rice noodle, noodles with xo sauce, chicken feet. The new foods were mushroom steam buns, soy sauce fried noodles and these salt and pepper tofu. They were to die for. They were little square fried pieces of tofu and the inside was soft,steamed tofu not chewy or spongy. 
I recommend this place to anyone that likes dim sum or looking to try it.
author: Michelle P.

description:
The dim sum here is ok. Do not order anything else.

The chicken dishes, specifically the Kung pao chicken and chicken and broccoli dishes do not taste like chicken. The "meat" in them is chewy and does not taste good. They also have a bad problem with flies. We will not be going back.
author: H K.

description:
The food is excellent! !!
The service is very good! !!
The price is right! !!
The place is neat and clean 
Nice place for good dinner!
author: Juan H.

description: The dim sum platter is def worth all the monies!! And we also had the dried scallop and egg white fried rice, which was delicious as well. :))) oh and their happy hour appetizer, which is free with a purchase of a beer/wine, is pretty small but i guess I can't complain haha happy hour is 5-7pm everyday!
author: Christine L.

description: Solid dim sum in the neighborhood, not crowded, no line, reasonably priced for the win! We tried the classic shrimp dumpling, shrimp with peashoot, rice noodles, fried rice, chow mein, bbq buns, chicken feet, egg tarts, all legit good dim sum.
author: Angela L.

description:
Dim Sum for dinner? Count me in

Came here with a group of rowdy frat boys on a Thursday night ( it borders the Marina).

It's a restaurant connected to a hotel. 

The ladies that work there are very nice and accommodating. 

We brought our own alcohol which they had no problem with, but be courteous,clean up, and leave with what you brought in.

Food was surprisingly really good. 

Hitters:
1) HK Style Pan Fried Noodles
2) Steamed BBQ Pork Buns
3) Calamari

Great for a big group who are frugal. You will not spend more than $25 a person here unless you order everything on the menu.
author: Virginia Q.

description: Cheap, fast, delicious. Almost always we find a table and the place is always moderately busy. My favorite are the spare ribs.
author: Rubail B.

description:
Super disappointing place. Actually SOUGHT IT OUT as we love dimsum wherever we go - and assuming it's literally in the name, went straight for it on a Cold rainy evening. 

The server was slightly rushed, she and a man who seemed to be the manager were rushing through taking our order. Not many dim sum options, with more Chinesey options like baby broccolini in oyster sauce and Chinese noodles etc. 

The ventilation (does not exist) as they have an open kitchen in the middle of the dining hall, and the windows were al Sears shut. After a hails the heat from the stirfry really got my cheeks burning and I was kinda hot (and the food wasn't!) so it made me even more ready to get the cheque and get on moving! The dimsums were okay, and I'm pretty sure there are better ones out there. All in all.. Womp womp
author: Pia S.

description:
It is part of a hotel at Van Ness street. We didnt expect there is a dim sum restaurant there. It wasnt as crowded as Hong Kong Lounge or Yank Sing on Sunday afternoon. My boyfriend and I got seated right away. We ordered stuffs we usually order at Dim Sum restaurant such as siumai and shrimp dumpling. 

Beside that :
- oolong tea : it tastes weird
- siumai : it was good, freshly served and taste good. It was the first dish that came to our table so it raised our expectation on the other dishes.
- chow mein : it was okay. But they put tons of meat, seafood, veggies in it.
- chicken feet with black bean sauce : it was too salty for me so i ended up not finishing it.
- deep fried durian pancakes were pretty good. 

Service:
Quick and friendly. 

Parking :
A bit hard to find parking spot here on Sunday but i am not sure about the other days.

Ambience : 
Even though it is like a place where you will get a breakfast buffet during your stay at the hotel, it is clean enough for chinese food restaurant. It is not that big, compare to hong kong lounge.
author: Ulrica J.

description: Highly recommend for "steamed salted egg yolk custard Bun","Shanghai dumpling". "steamed spare ribs w/plum sauce" is nice but a little bit oil, "chicken feet w/ black bean sauce " tastes sweet, but I personally prefer the salty one.
author: Jie Z.

description:
My wife ordered Chicken with Double Mushroom,  I ordered Mongolian Beef (spicy), and we shared an order of steamed rice. 

The Mongolian Beef came out first and it was very bland with little to no flavor. Several pieces of beef, white onion, and green onion in a brown sauce, which was soaked up in the crispy noodles they served under everything.  I would not order again and if the server bothered to ask, I would have recommended they look into changing the dish.

The Chicken with double mushroom dish was very good and was twice the portion of the Mongolian Beef dish, which was good,  because we didn't eat much of the Mongolian Beef. The mushrooms were fresh and cooked just right so they weren't mushy. The chicken was also very good: Not fatty scraps a lot of restaurants use. 

The rice was the normal sticky rice found everywhere: no better,  no worse.

Service was mixed: We were seated promptly, water was refilled several times, but there was no follow up after the food was served and the beef dish was served several minutes before the chicken dish.

It's what you would expect from a restaurant attached to a hotel.
author: Pat T.

description: impressed by the authenticity and quality of this place! came here for lunch (by myself, lol) on a monday during my funemployment week. it's a weird location - lobby of a hotel on van ness - for a chinese restaurant.  the interiors look a little run-down.. i ordered four things (cuz im a certified fatty) - soup dumplings, gai lan with oyster sauce, beef chow fun, and half of a roasted duck.  the first two items were kind of a fail - dumplings tasted a bit sour (withOUT the vinegar) and gai lan pieces were HUGE and literally just served with oyster sauce for dipping. yikes. can make this at home for 3 cents.  however the beef chow fun and duck more than made up for the flop.  massive serving of perfectly stir fried chow fun! nomomnom and their spicy sauce is delicious!  the roasted duck was fatty and flavorful and i had to resist eating the entire dish in a single sitting.  $52 after tax and tip for this meal (with plenty leftover) and $1 for tea (?!). would come back!
author: Christina L.

description:
Dim Sum on Van Ness!?!?   Real dim sum on Van Ness!   

YEAH!   Good price and amazing selection.  Near my work and has clean tables to boot.
author: Mark B.

description:
This place was recommended as a great place for Shanghai steamed dumplings by San Francisco magazine. They are pretty dismal, go to Yank sing instead.

The dim sum is about average. I like Cityview near Chinatown better. If you're a dim sum newbie, this place would be fine for you

Any restaurant that has dim sum at night is automatically on the suspect list.
author: Ellen H.

description: Loved our meal here, where the dim sum was made fresh to order rather than wheeled out on carts which is how we usually experience it.  Delicious dumplings,  barbecue pork buns and pea shoot dumplings, followed by a to-die-for mango pudding.  Awesome!!
author: Anita B.

description:
Amazing! 
A hole in the wall Dim sum spot that have only 1/3 of the line compared to other popular dim sum spots around town.
Not to mention that their Shanghai soup dumplings are amazing! The skin of the soup dumpling is not too thick compared to other dumpling spots.

The decor is a little less glamorous compare to Yang Sing or Hakkasan of course.
This is the "traditional" canton style dim sum. 

Must order: 
Shanghai Soup dumplings
Siu Mai
Shrimp Dumpling
Sticky rice in lotus leaf
Chicken feet 

Coming from Hong Kong I didn't think that any other place can top the usual spots you find in china town.

Not a single dish is ever served "warm" 
They are "hot" and fresh. Simply delicious.

The quality of the food is amazing for the price you pay.

Don't come here if you're looking for a place for ambiance or fusion dim sum.
author: Alui L.

description:
I chopped off 3 the stars after the health score plunged and I have not been back. I always check the health score before I head out. 

 I went for the dim sum they get it right.
Made with Quality ingredients, made with care, 
Good textures, nicely seasoned and served piping hot, 
The dim sum is nicely sized so the stuffing balances with the shell size and thickness.

The ingredient in the steamed dumplings are tastier and have a better texture in every case than at other several other over priced big name rivals.

In the evening you can order right off the menue and they make the dim sum fresh and piping hot especially for you 
Your dim sum will not be roving around the restaurant on a trolley looking for takers on getting cold and rubbery
Even at 6 pm there is a sufficient selection of delicious dim sum on the menus to satisfy your dim sum cravings. 

For price and quality The Dim Sum Club is right in my sweet
author: Joseph M.

description: Awesome place!! Happy hour includes complimentary egg roll and the dim sum was incredible!  Best pork & shrimp Siu Mai I have ever had!
author: Brian H.

description:
We read pretty good reviews about this restaurant. But i was disappointed by pretty much everything. Parking was hard to find, waitresses were rude, chinese donut that comes with the porridge tasted terrible, walnut shrimp for $15 was smothered with mayo (panda express has it better), Shanghai dumplings were okay but i had better and even the soy ginger sauce they made for us tasted weird i made my own sauce with their condiments. 

Im still looking for a good dumpling spot in sf but this place definitely is NOT the one!
author: Yoon C.

description: This place is pretty amazing since they offer dim sum at all hours. Just when you get the hankering for dim sum but it just so happens to be 6 p.m., they're open and serving. This place was my introduction to dim sum and I must say that this place has got me hooked.
author: Abraham A.

description:
The food tastes really good.  The place looks really clean.  But it gets really scary when you realize that your food could be recycled from other customers'.

Story:

We forgot what we marked in our dim sum sheet - it was too many.  So we didn't realize we didn't order turnip cake.

A waitress delivered the turnip cake to us.  We couldn't wait and 3 of us had our chopsticks dug into the cakes, trying to break it up into quarters.

That's when a chubby / pale skinned (head) waitress with dyed hair came by and told us that's actually not ours and took it away.  Fair enough.

What comes next is disturbing... 

3 waitresses crowd around the plate of turnip cake at the end of the kitchen and started discussing what to do with it.  What the (head, pale skinned, jade bracelet) waitress (that doesn't smile) ended up doing was slicing it even more with a scissors to make it look intentionally chopped.  Then she delivered the cakes to the table right next to us!

So the table next to us ended up eating turnip cakes that we fondled.  Sorry boss!

---

Also updates with the quality:

- Roast duck dish got smaller, no sauce.  Still crispy though.
- Fried donut rice crepe got smaller as well.

But in general things still taste good.  Just suspicious where things come from!
author: Koalie W.

description: There aren't too many soup dumplings or restaurants that rival Din Tai Fung, and this one does. The soup dumplings are incredible, as well as the rest of the menu. This restaurant is by far a hidden gem. I would come back here in a heart beat!
author: Alexis A.

description: No matter that a warning comes up about the health rating. And what others have said, my wife and I found no overt sign of this. The place is still busy, the food was good and served hot, tho' the onion pancakes were over fried. Service was mediocre and it took a while for them to collect the bill. Still a go to place for a quick dimsum fix.
author: Ifti K.

description: If you're looking for a quick dim sum fix,  this is a good spot to go to. Good service and decent food.
author: Arking G.

description:
{ OVERALL :: 4 stars }
^ would i come back : YES, and frequently do
^ would i recommend this place : YES, depends :) 
^ dim sum better than HKFL : NO
^ if no, why go : typically no wait, closer to me, parking is relatively easier and the most important part, food is still pretty good
^ similarly to HKFL, you order by marking the items on a menu. ensures your item is hot and items don't 'run out' by the time they get to your table :)

{ FOOD :: 4 stars }
WHAT TO GET:
^ duck, i get the peking style w/the buns and boneless
^ pan fried shrimp + leek dumplings
^ har gow
^ baked bbq pork bun
^ steamed custard bun
CLOSE, BUT COULD BE BETTER:
^ shrimp noodle roll - they make these fresh, you can watch if you sit at the counter pretty cool to see!
^ XLB - needs more broth inside and more dipping sauce
^ sui mai - may even be a *skip* item

{ SERVICE :: 3.5 stars }
^ waitress, so far most of our waitresses have been pretty good. they don't necessarily come around and ask if you're ok or need anything, however they do proactively fill up your water, and you're not necessarily wanting anything... making eye contact usually gets their attention
^ host, 9 times out of 10 the guy who i assume is the manager oversees the restaurant.  the flow is pretty spot on when he's there.  he greets guests, directs everyone, etc.  but when he's not there chaos ensues (new years day)

{ ATMOSPHERE :: 2 stars }
^ decor : little to no decor, buffet area in the middle of the restaurant also kills any ambiance it might be able to achieve, reminds me of a cafeteria 
^ cleanliness : so far so good, nothing negative to report
^ noise level, not too bad. you can hear the other conversations next to you - which isn't always a good thing

{ MISC }
^ parking, street.  we've been luckily and have typically been able to find parking within 5 mins (2 rounds of circling the restaurant at a max)

happy eating!
author: Tina F.

description: Amazing! Had all sorts of dim sum. Also, they serve dim sum for dinner - very rare. Had imperial peking duck carved tableside as well. Great service.
author: Victor O.

description: Bad experience - service was good, but quality of dumplings was off and paid for it later when I got very sick and had food poisoning.
author: Charles F.

description: Flavorful and authentic mapo tofu - good selection of dim sum.  Ordered several dishes to split and paid $20/each.  Restaurant is clean and was pretty empty on a Friday night around 7:30pm for some reason.  Will be back!
author: Emily W.

description:
Wow, do not believe the hype on these reviews for anyone with dimsum standards. Yes, it's true there's no other dimsum in Russian Hill, but it does NOT, I repeat, does NOT compare to the quality of dimsum you can get at HK Lounge or Good Mong Kok Bakery.

I ordered the dimsum dinner platter and XLB, and the dimsum tasted like it was store bought and frozen minutes earlier. Terrible quality, not juicy. Just... overpriced and mediocre. They should be offering a full dimsum menu during dinner if you are to call yourselves "Dim Sum Club" -- there were so many entrees on the menu, I was feeling very confused about expectations. XLB was okay... some of them were extremely smaller compared to the others and didn't have any soup in them.

$20 without tip, and I wasn't full at the end of the meal. Is that what a dimsum meal is supposed to feel like? The only good thing was that the wait staff was nice and friendly, and you don't have to wait for a table. But I'm here to rate the food and it was not all that. Just something to fulfill the cravings if you're too lazy to go to Chinatown/Richmond District.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Hidden gem, best Chinese food in the city. Very clean tasting and yummy. We like the dumplings, wonton soup and chicken with broccoli and Mongolian beef. Just wish they delivered.
author: Melissa R.

description:
What is with these reviews? Huge huge Yelp miss. I'm not exaggerating when I tell you this is probably the worst Chinese food, maybe any food, I've had in my entire life.

This place opened and I was curious about it, especially with the predominantly positive Yelp reviews.

I honestly tried to block out this place from my memory, but a few friends and I ordered a few non-dim sum dishes here. I believe it was a chicken and vegetable dish, chow mein, and 2 other dishes. 

Every single one of us were very unsatisfied with our dishes. For me--my gripe was that the chicken was extremely low quality meat and tasted as if there might be cartilage or something in it. It was extremely tough and chewy.

Perhaps their dim sum is actually better and we should have stuck with that, but after the experience we've had here there's no way I would return
author: Issa A.

description: The dim sum was okay, not great.  The staff is friendly.  I'm very surprised this place has 4 stars.
author: J. D.

description: Food was good and everything till it came time for the bill. We paid in some cash and the rest on the card and didn't expect not to have a tip. So as we are leaving the waitress come to get the bill and sees no tip then asked about the tip?!?! I understand completely about the tip but when we explained why we couldn't tip she hour upset and instead that we tip her with the card and we continued to tell her we didn't have enough for the tip and we paid for our food tipping is not a right you deserve of you act like this after not being tipped. So as we are going back and forth she would not let my friend get out the booth so we can leave instead she kept insisting that we tip her for her services. I also asked to speak with a manager and she ignored me I even went over to tell her how unprofessional that was also to my surprise ignored again. Overall food was great the place is nice but your staff needs to respect when that can't be tipped as long as we paid the tax and for the food we should be able to leave and not harassed about a tip especially the way they act after being told I'm not getting a tip.
author: Jhon D.

description: Honestly this was the dirties restaurant I've ever been to. Dead bugs in dishes!!!! Gross!
author: Marissa C.

description:
With 9 folks total,  my family and I celebrated my mom's 76th birthday with dim sum lunch.   We ordered  and enjoyed the following:  

Shanghai dumplings   $7.50
potstickers, $4.50
 beef porridge, $7.95
 Preserved  egg with pork porridge,  $7.95
hai gow,  $6.50
Sui Mai,   $4.95  
pork crepe $5.75
 shrimp crepe  $6.75
 vegetarian crepe,  $4.75
steamed chicken feet,  $4.25
sticky rice,  $4.25
 veggie dumpling, $4.25
 deep fried calamari,  $6.95
steamed bbq pork buns,   $4.25
Baked Pineapple crust covered Bbq pork buns $4.25
 shrimp paste mushroom,  $5.50
shrimp paste with eggplant,   $5.50
black sesame mochi, $3.50
sesame balls $3.50
Spring onion pancake $4.25
Fried Taro dumpling $4.25 

The  tea and water were refilled constantly.  Great customer service.  Spent a little over an one hour in the establishment. Took home leftovers!    Will come back again!  

My mom came here a total of 5 x.   This is my first time.
author: E. C.

description:
The hotel was once, drug dealers and users famous hang-out, and the most famous Drug-Whore House in SF. The location used be "little Joe's" before? And,.. in a short time, it was a Mexican, whatever...
But not anymore, because the Dim Sum Club is here for change!

The waitress forgot our order and the waiter doesn't speak English, but so what?
What I saw was that many really hard working Asians giving their best to keep this dim sum business going.

This is what we had:

Pan-fried potstickers (4/3.75)
wellcooked, really hot insides.

BBQ Pork bun (3 for $4.25)
doughy bun texture, fillings taste was OK, I don't mind that loaded with msg.

Beef Chow Fun, $10
What a Great portion! Taste less salty, the Beef was very tender.

Steamed Chinese Broccoli w/ oyster sauce, $6.50
the Chinese Broccoli was Steamed and the oyster sauce was on the side.

Shanghai Dumpling, $5.50, 6 pieces: 
This was surprisingly good. I've ordered this at countless dimsum places and the outside was always thick and the inside was never juicy, but this was good! Thin outer layer and the meat was very juicy and aromatic. 

Curry Samosas, $3.95: wow. This was surprisingly really good. The flavors really hit us and it was a great snack to have. The dipping sauce was pretty good and wasn't watered down. Definitely give this a try!

Veggie dumplings, $4.25, 4 pieces, Excellent dish! hot and fresh green dumpling was nice and chewy, w/ diced mushroom inside, 

Fried Chicken Wings, $4.50, 4 pieces, Excellent, by taking one of the two bones out and pushing all the meat to one end to make it look like a lollipop, and deep fried, come with sliced jalapeño, Salt and Pepper, the crust was not too thick. Nice and juicy flavor. Came with a mayo dipping sauce but I did not need it!

Beef w/ Cilantro Noodle Roll, $4.25, Very good! The rice noodle crepe was thin and smooth. The beef was also very tasty! 

The place seems safe, no more drugs, but msg and soy sauce.
I will support this restaurant because what I had and the service.
I will be back!
author: Nobu K.

description: Great dim sum find North of Market! Get the fried sticky rice, soup dumplings, pan fried shrimp and chive dumplings and the shumai.
author: Bethany D.

description:
I agree with the previous Yelp reviewers. Dim sum club is a gem in the Cow Hollow-ish area! The restaurant is smaller but we got seated for 8 people at 1pm easily. 

The caveat is you order from a menu, not from people pushing carts. Nonetheless, everything was good, nothing was average. 

Things we ordered:
-Shu mai
-har gow 
-fried taro root
-fried pork puff (football)
-shrimp noodle (aka shrimp chow fun)
-curry Samosas
-spare ribs
-soup dumplings
-porridge
-shrimp chives dumplings

Everything tasted perfect, nothing tasted horribly. It was an extremely satisfying meal for some of us hungover people.
author: Linda N.

description: The food is really good, but be careful, the restaurant itself gets HOT - probably from the open kitchen. If you're looking for some good dim sum near the marina this is a good option. They don't have the carts that they push around, but they have a wide selection on their menu. Super cost effective too :)
author: Alison Y.

description:
It looked sketchy from the outside, didn't seem like a good place to eat in. But luckily we logged on to yelp and read some reviews, they all recommended it. We went ahead and orders a lot of food, mostly dumplings. Probably the best dumplings I've had in 18 years. The manager came out to ask us if we were enjoying our food and seemed like a friendly guy. It was mostly Asians in the restaurant which I guess can be interpreted as a good thing.
I'm glad we went in and I recommend you all to do the same if you enjoy good Chinese food.
author: Lucia C.

description:
11.08.14 | bookmarked 09.24.14

My usual routine is to venture out to the Richmond for dim sum. But I keep passing by this place on the way to work. And Yelp had it at 4 stars. I just had to check it out for myself.

We arrived around 1:30 and were seated right away. It's a basic cafe feeling, no frills, bells, or whistles. I'm cool with that, as long as the food is good.

We get to our usual: chinese donut with noodle roll; siu mai; beef balls; bean curd roll; turnip cake. We added two noodle dishes.

Everything was fine. The flavoring was a bit bland on all the dishes for me. Maybe it's missing MSG (haha).

Total damage for five: $70
author: Jenny L.

description:
Still can't get over how bad our experience was! HOW is this place 4 stars on yelp???

We have dim sum once a week, usually at Yank Sing or Hakkasan.. so when I heard about this new place in Russian hill we were super excited to try!

Unfortunately, the food and service were so disappointing we will not be returning! In fact, it was SO BAD that we walked up the slope to Loving cup so that we could cleanse our palettes with some yummy frozen yogurt.

Ambience is like a food court, but hey if the foods phenomenal that's okay. 

* Xiao Lung bao / shanghainese soup dumplings: Meat to soup ratio ALL WRONG and just not good. we ate 3/6.

* Shrimp dumpling: Filling was ok but skin way too thick.

Actually I'm not going bother listing out all the dim sum we had because nothing was memorable. The curry samosas were probably the best, lotus sticky rice was alright and so were the baked BBQ pork buns but that's about it.

Waste of calories, bad service, dirty glasses and take away boxes.. A place that is almost empty at 12 noon on a Saturday is never a good sign.
author: Amber S.

description: Good not great. My group liked the shumai and pork buns a lot but thought the XLB were bland. Not sure that the higher price is worth it.
author: Nicole L.

description: Love it! The crispy duck is delicious, steamed pork buns are wonderful and the pork & shrimp sui mai are a must have!!!
author: Ashley W.

description: Really really good dim sum and quality Chinese food for people living in pac heights / Russian hill / cow hollow who do want to go all the way to Chinatown or Richmond area for authentic Chinese food. We ordered shrimp dumplings, shanghai dumplings and pecking duck on lunar new year night. The dumplings were steaming hot and well made. The duck was carved in front of us. All made with quality ingredients and less oil. This will be my go to Chinese food in the neighborhood.
author: Josie S.

description:
Dear Dim Sum Club, please please please please please don't change anything about how you currently prepare your dim sum, because it is SO GOOD.

Honestly, I was very skeptical about this place, being that it's in Russian Hill, bordering Cow Hollow/Marina land. However, I was very pleasantly surprised. All the way from very good tea to super fresh dim sum - I left a very pleased (slightly food coma-ed customer).

The only downside is that my XLB (soup dumpling) stuck to the container and either broke before I could taste the soup, or had very little soup in it. I think I just had bad luck because my bf (see Jeff N.'s review) did not have any issue with his XLB - all of his had a lot of soup in it. 

I will definitely be back.
author: Stephanie L.

description: The dim sum here is worth chasing down. Took us a half hour to locate a parking space, but the exquisite shao long bao, Shanghai-style dumplings, made it all worth it. Tables on the side were a tight squeeze, which only added the feeling of being in Asia. Highly recommended.
author: Bruce H.

description: Loved everything about it. best pork sticky buns ever. i ate so much food all by myself
author: Sierra B.

description: If I could give this place 3.5 stars I would. Not quite a 4, but definitely good for the location and price. I came here looking to get my dim sum fix but not wanting to travel to the Richmond or Chinatown. The ambience was lacking, but there wasn't a wait and all the food was made to order. There are no carts here so be sure you know what you are looking for. Luckily the menu is in Chinese and English with descriptions that give you a pretty good idea of what you are ordering. I ordered the standard Siu Mai, BBq pork buns, Hagao and some chun fun. One thing to note here is tea is not free, but only $1 a person. This place definitely caters to novice dim sum goers as well as seasoned ones. Their selection could grow a little, but definitely if you are looking for your staple dim sum selection in the Marina/Cow Hollow area, this is the place for you!
author: Alex L.

description: This place has a good location, easy to park, not like most of the Chinatown restaurants. Overall this place is nice and is a little bit pricey comparing to Chinatown's Dim Sum. I can tell there are more white people here as well. Everything is nice, good service. The only thing is that all dishes are not as tasty as in Chinatown, but I don't know why. Especially the fried dumplings, it is obviously made from frozen ones. However, If I am really annoyed by the parking in Chinatown I might consider coming again.
author: Chen L.
Anna L.

description: This place is great! Went in and had great Dim sum and didn't have to go to Clement st or China Town. Food was very good service was great and it wasn't a million bucks. You will have to flag down servers for any extras but they were super nice and very efficient. I will go back for sure.
author: thomas P.

description:
Dim Sum Club is a great restaurant because of the unique combination of the following:

1. Location: Within walking distance of Russian Hill, Nob Hill, Pac Heights - areas that traditionally lack good dim sum eats.

2. Dim Sum at all (open) hours: You can get dim sum for dinner! For takeout! To supplement a meal! As your entire meal!

3. Decent food: Of course, (1) and (2) would be meaningless if the food wasn't good - but it is. Set your expectations in that while it's not the absolute best the city has to offer, it is consistent and delicious. The sesame balls are most definitely above-par. The sticky rice dishes are great too. Xiao long bao has a slightly tough skin but is still quite good.

Overall, I feel lucky to have this as a dim sum option nearby for dine-in and takeout.
author: Alyssa W.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of their dim sum. Made reservations for 16 and they easily accommodated us. Next time, we'll bring some bottles of champagne for Sunday fun day brunch.
author: Vicky T.

description:
Great value for the quality of dim sum. Usually, we give a place a few months to get to a decent level of consistent quality. This could be my go to place for dim sum for a while. 

Location kinda sucks. I mean, who goes to van ness? This might be a problem since you need to find parking, but I didn't have a problem on a Saturday morning. 

Inside, there is a review below that says they only have 7 tables. This is BS. Its not a big place, but they have north of 15 takes and can probably seat 75. 

The dim sum is great. Shrimps are big, there is not really a bunch of undesirable filler, not to salty.   E also think they make their own chili because it is potent!  Dessert dim sum were kinda small, but tasty. 

5 of us over ordered and had some dishes from the main menu and still got put for under $100.
author: Wes W.

description: The food is pretty good overall. The only complain is the air circulation is bad. The kitchen is right in the seating area. I end up walk out smell like food.
author: Kristina F.

description:
We have been to this place a few times. Always has consistent good food and the value is great. Doesn't have trolley service but the food is ready quickly. 
The noodle roll is definitely my favourite
author: Renata M.

description: The food here was really bland. I guess it's something I'm not accustomed to. My husband and I ordered the pork buns and the beef and scrambled eggs over rice. Again, a bit to flavorless and bland for our liking. The customer service wasn't great either. :(
author: Vielka V.

description: Food is here not bad. It is awkwardly located next to da vinci villas. Food here I must say is really good and at a very good price. We tried the vegetable mixed and fried calamaris and it was awesome. This place is very hidden and not many people come here but food is very traditional cantonese food. It is not the best but certainly has great flavors.
author: Daniel C.

description: I wasn't super satisfied at Dim Sum Club. I was intrigued by their interpretation of the baked pork bun because it has a flaky top and isn't glazed, however it was very interesting and definitely tasty. And the steamed bao was on the same level-- although you can tell they use a lot of fatty pieces. I like it fatty but it doesn't need to be artery-clogging. But the shu mai and shrimp rice noodle were lacking in flavor BIG TIME.
